content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
VERDICT:Buy Immediately (9.8/10)Completion Time: 25-30 hoursBottom Line: "Don't just play this game for the memorable story, the characters, or the adventure, JUST DO IT FOR THE KIDS MAN."PROS+Awesome story+Suprisingly mature humor+Winning gameplay formula+Hilarious characters+Unique worldCONS-You will sometimes get lost-Platforming difficultiesREVIEWThis is an adult's game disguised in XS kids clothing. On the outside, this is a game about a children's day camp, but venture a little deeper and you'll find one of the most quarky, hilarious, and enthralling adventures that successfully stands the test of time.Our hero is Rasputin (AKA Raz), a young boy that runs away from his job at the circus in order to hone his supernatural abilities at a day camp for young psychics. It only takes a day for him to realize that something is terribly wrong: some of the campers are starting to literally lose their minds. It is your job to not only become an official psychic expert, but to find the culprit behind the missing brains!This is your traditional adventure-platformer in the same vain as Mario 64 or the Spyro franchise. You'll be running around completing tasks for different camp patrons to advance the story, all while traversing terrain and taking down baddies.Let me just say that this cast of characters is one of the most endearingly dysfunctional groups of people you'll ever meet. From delusional old men to stereotypical FBI agents to a bully with a lisp, all the classic stereotypes are in full force here.Gameplay is split into two different zones: free roam and brain sequences. During free roam you can roam the camp grounds searching for collectables and meeting new people. Brain sequences take place inside your brain and involve whimsical levels reminiscent of a bad dream, or someone that's tripping really hard. Everything in this game, regardless of location, has the same distinct art style, and this is the type of style that doesn't age with time.The gameplay itself is incredibly fun. Throughout the game you'll be gaining new abilities to take on your foes. These include telekenesis, levetation, invisibility, and more. Each ability has its purpose, and will come into play at some point in the game. There are also many puzzle aspects of gameplay, and these puzzles are damn fun. My favorite puzzle was when I had to play a game of Catan (not actually Catan but something similar) in order to defeat a boss. It was one of the coolest levels I have ever played.The cons are few and in between. Sometimes I got lost in this game, and it was unclear where I needed to go to advance the story. Also, some platforming sections were frustrating, or it wasn't necessarily obvious what I had to do to advance in the level. Regardless of these hiccups, I always managed to find my way eventually.If there's one thing I want you to take away from this review its this: this game is memorable. Each level is incredibly unique. Each character is different and has their own idiosycracies that make them hilarious. Each boss fight has different mechanics that make you think. And the last level is a tremendous challenge that makes you feel like you've accomplished something monumental upon its completion.Don't just play this game for the memorable story, the characters, or the adventure, JUST DO IT FOR THE KIDS MAN.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2016
												First by all, let me say this is not a normal game, this is a masterpiece.As a fan of graphic adventures and of Double Fine i approached to this game with the wrong thinking that it was another adventure with some platform elements, well, i was totally wrong, cause this is a 100% platform with some elements of adventure.This could have been a 100% game but cause of few flaws i can't give to it the top score and i will try to explain why. underlining the negative parts.First thing above all, the camera control is automatic, altough you can manually change it while playing, in the most hot actions you'll not think to change the camera while you're trying to jump and survive, so the result of this is that camera, sometime, suddenly changes making you jump in a wrong direction despite the one you wanted to go, this is a minor problem and happens just in few points but is enough for me to cut some score points.Second thing, i grow up with platforms in a time when graphic adventures (and most of all other kind of games) almost did not exist, so let me say i have quite some experiences in platforms, but this game will, occasionally, challenge your patience, cause some sections of jumps will be extremely annoying.The punching mini game you find in the beginning is one of the most annoying mini games ever i have played in long time, i really think here devs gone a bit too over in demaning things to complete it.Some of the achievements force you to do some of the most annoying grinding gathering you have ever done.The real strength of this game is in the plot and the story, it's very, very nice and will entertain you with a good portion of the best humor you can find inside an insane game (yes because all characters are really insane, literally ^^ )Being a game of 2005, the graphics are amazing, really awesome artworks from great artists.As a my personal opinion and preference i would have preferred that Double Fine had focused more on the adventure portion, adding more puzzles and less platform, but the final result remains outstanding giving to the player an unique gaming experience that will last long thanks to the good longevity of the game.My Final Score is 93 /100

content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												Seriously people, it's a cult classic for a reason. If you're planning on buying this wait until it's on crazy sale (Bought my copy when it was going for practically 1.75$ CAN ) because around the halfway point when there's not much left to learn the game gets MAD difficult, and if you buy it for the 9.99$ current full price, you might feel like you have wasted your money. Besides that, who honestly doesn't want to fool (Without spoiling anything) agents into thinking you're one of them? Or become Godzilla? Of hell, simply light things on fire? This game really has it all in lue of imagenation (Here's looking at you Godzilla level that took me forever). Plus you get to play as a kid from the circus that decided to run away from it (Rather than TO it as many children must have planned to do at some point in childhood before they were allowed to cross the streets by themselves... I know I did... Sat on the curb for three hours huffing that my plans had been foiled by the road, what can I say, I was -and still am- adventerous) All in all, it's a darn good game. You'd be hard pressed to find another Tim Schafer gem like this one... Critisizm would be that darn difficulty curve... Oh and like, four of the kids in the game are aggrivatingly annoying as ♥♥♥♥, but at least there's only one 'Escort' thing that's totally optional, but nets you some sweet, sweet arrowheads (Money in this game) if you do it (And it's simple as hell if you're quick to reassure the character that they can make it). Other than that, it's a really good game.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												The writing is very funny, which you won’t see in this industry very often, because in this apparently, in this industry stupid drama is better than smart comedy. The story is very original and interesting, I don’t wish to spoil it so you will have to trust me on this one. Every character has his own personality and struggles, even the unimportant ones, which is nice to see in this land of Mr. Johnny Testosterone Space Marine and Mrs. Sassy Action Chick.    The gameplay is intresting, but it has it’s flaws (they might be forgivable), the psychic powers are awesome and the boss fights really require skill, every boss has it’s own weak spot, you have to deduce it by watching it’s attacks. On the other hand the camera can be a little female dog some times. The combat outside the boss fights is kind of meh. The difficulty curve is a little bit messed up, there were sequences near the end that almost made break my keyboard. However I never stopped playing it, because I really wanted to see the ending, and I haven’t left disappointed.  The ending promised a sequel and I really hope to see the day when Psychonauts 2 will be released!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2016
												As a fan of 3D platformers with a spare dollar to spend during a Steam sale, I decided to give Double Fine Productions' cult classic Psychonauts a try. After hearing about the alleged creativity and uniqueness the game offered, I wondered if the reviews were to be believed.  Psychonauts follows the adventure of an eager young psychic named Razputin as he uncovers the secrets behind Whispering Rock Psychic Summer Camp, along with the minds of various characters around the area. When things take a turn for the worst, it becomes up to him to put an end to it and save his fellow campers. Though the distinct graphical style may initially scare some players off, its fits the tone of the game to a 'T'. Psychonauts seems to take much of its inspiration from Western animation in terms of its character tropes and setting, and it definitely works. Combined with the superb voice acting, interesting plot and remarkable concept, the atmosphere is definitely an enjoyable one. Along with the characters and overall mood the game gives off, the level design and gameplay is superb. The hub area is a nice concept, allowing the player to see what their favorite campers are up to while they take a break from the story. Along with housing numerous secret items, it also allows them to quickly transmit to and fro each section at will. Being a game called "Psychonauts", it certainly shines during the levels taking place in the minds Razputin enters. Each of these possesses a unique feeling and theme to reflect the personality of the character in question. Each level also hosts their own set of challenges, and will make the player eager to progress and see what awaits them. Unfortunately, there is not much left to be explored of each world once it is cleared for the first time – the player only needs to return unless they are aiming to gather all the collectable items.On an entirely different note, the player is given an item early in the game that allows them to ask for advice if they are stuck. The advice offered is simple, yet effective and allows the player to work around most obstacles without the game flat-out doing it for them. The game does not push or force the player to use this feature, allowing this to appeal to both those who are easily frustrated and those who want to work things out for themselves.Of course no game is perfect, and Psychonauts is no exception to this rule. While I do not intend to sound like a certain critic featured within the game, Psychonauts possesses a few flaws which prevent it from becoming my absolute favorite. The keyboard controls feel very confusing and complicated, making a controller almost necessary to play this game; although once this is done it handles rather nicely. A certain level in the game titled "The Milkman Conspiracy" prevents you from progressing unless you purchase an expensive item which removes the object blocking the path, which have previously only appeared in locations that would indicate this would be an optional side quest. Though the game warns the player of this obstacle beforehand, this still forces them to tediously grind for currency. The very same level also possesses a more puzzle-based structure which requires a copious amount of backtracking as well as repeatedly searching the area for objects which can easily be missed. A miniboss is also fought here twice with no warning, variation, or possibility of skipping. While this is an understandable attempt to give the level some of the action offered by previous worlds, it becomes tedious and annoying when introduced in this fashion. Thankfully, this area is one of the game's most humor-rich areas which makes up for a good deal of its flaws, but it still is far from ideal. Though the game has its imperfections here and there, Psychonauts is certainly an enjoyable and memorable experience for fans of the platformer genre. On a final note - if you do purchase the game, be wary that much of the game's content is spoiled through achievements and trading cards.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2012
												Get this game! Psychonauts is one of those gems you most likely have missed out on. It pulls you through your "victims" brain and you see the world as they see it. This makes the world look brilliantly different when considering that some of the brain-owners are slightly or completely insane. I would play it just for the strange setting and the sheer weirdness of the worlds. At the bottom of it all, it is a semi action-adventure-platformer which utilizes "spells"(or rather "brain spells" such as telekinesis) to get to the objective. If you are even remotely interested in either platformers or adventure games you should already have played this game. Only bad things I can come to think of is that the camera is a bit wonky at times(which sadly was the case for all 3d platformers back when this was released), the difficulty sort of explodes at a certain point in the game(in other words; it's not a natural evolving difficulty curve), and (SLIGHT SPOILER WARNING!!! SLIGHT SPOILER WARNING!!!)Towards the end you are locked inside the brain dimension due to actions taken in the outside world.  This makes it impossible to get the remaining collectible items if you are into that sort of things.(END SLIGHT SPOILER! END SLIGHT SPOILER!)All in all it's an amazing game and you can get it for under 10€ which makes it a bargain.Get it, play it, love it. Hypnotoad demands it!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												Wow this game...wow..i mean..the characters, the music, the worlds, THE FREAKIN WORLDS. Okay enough with the gushing. Ths game is not as hyped as it should be. Double fine and Tim Schafer are quite good and imaginative and that is most apparent in games like this one and Brutal Legend (which i love as well). Originally PS2 era, the steam port is not that bad. A controler wouldn't hurt becuase some of the platforming is a bit annoying with keyboard and mouse. The story? You play Razputin (or just Raz) who sneaks away from his circus life to attend a summer camp for a group of traniee psychic agents known as "Psychonauts". Raz's family, especially his father, are heavily opposed to pyschics, seeing as a pyschic cursred Raz's grand father to drown in  water, thus starting the belief that all in Raz's family share the curse. Wanting to break away from his circus life, he decides to join the psychonauts, who have the ability to enter different worlds in different people's minds. The world's are very creative, my favorite world is Black Veletopia becuase the colors were so great to look at. behind the game's quirky exterior, lies characters who have deep backgrounds and personaities that are hard to forget. This game is pretty under-rated and is worth a pick up. The highly imaginative worlds with hilarious, yet deep, characters are enough to entise anyone into the world of Pyschonauts.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2013
												I've enjoyed the other Double Fine games like Costume Quest and Stacking, but Psychonauts is something special. I honestly didn't expect a game of this magnitude. It's an amazing action, adventure, platformer with a wacky, yet funny story. The gameplay reminds me of Alice: Madness Returns, but it's actually way better. It offers excellent writing and voice acting, superb (although low res) cinematics, solid missions and quests, fun character building, and a small, but open world to explore. I'm still in awe at how good Psychonauts is--just hands down a great game.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
												Psychonauts has likeable characters, clever worldbuilding, and is overall full of personailty.That said, it REALLY shows that Tim was more used to adventure games than 3-D collect-a-thon platformers.When there are adventure-game-type puzzles (like Gloria's Theater or the Milkman Conspiracy), the game really shines. Unfortunately, that's not the majority of the game. The majority of the game involves gimmicky powers (I never used the shield outside the level you get it in, and Clairvoyance mostly just has comedic effect), very basic platforming (and even MORE basic combat), and some of the most tedious collect-a-thon-ing I've seen in any game.You may have noticed that, despite all this, I am still recommending the game. Why? Because it was a fun ride despite these glaring flaws. The atmosphere alone compensates for many of these issues tenfold. The various worlds you explore are neat, and the art style is solid.I'm glad I played it, I'm just unlikely to play it again.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2016
												I was always on the outside looking in when it came to Psychonauts. Never really played it when I was younger, but heard it was a great game from others. I decided to give it a try on a whim and was incredibly pleased with my decision.It is a phenomenal game.There are so many fun-loving, humorous portions of the game. While, at a closer look, you can pluck out some dark underlying sub-plots. These can range from intense paranoia, insanity, heartbreak, and obviously enough, death. You are playing around in a game and you are playing around in people's minds. There is so much twisted fun to be had.The one thing I would not recommend you do is play on mouse & keyboard. I tried to go as long as I could without a controller, but finally buckled and got one when it came to more "combat-heavy" sections of the game.TL;DR - You will not regret playing this. (Unless it leaves you wanting more and you have to wait for Psychonauts 2...)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2012
												I picked up Psychonauts after consistently hearing it referenced as one of the best games ever by people in the games industry. I'm in complete agreement - this is now one of my favorite games. I laughed out loud more often here than in any other game. The level design and variety of art styles is excellent. Gameplay is generally very good and the various psychic powers are fun to play with.Downsides: A few levels and collectible quests can be somewhat frustrating due to precise timing requirements alongside slightly finicky controls (definitely take the time to remap the key/mouse actions as the defaults can be difficult to work with). Also, there comes a point late in the game beyond which you can't go back to the main game area to complete collectible quests or achievements.Two people in our house have put in 150 hours of play on this game. We're playing on a Mac and this version has been smooth and stable with no issues.Update: I was prompted to revisit this review as part of the Steam Autumn Sale 2016. My comments on the game remain valid except for the last paragraph. When we first played the game, it was made as a PC port inside a Mac "wrapper" (Transgaming, I think). This can be problematic for newer, more powerful games, but suited Psychonauts just fine. At some point, however, Double Fine decided to rebuild the game as a native Mac game. This can be a great thing for a game that doesn't work well in a wrapper, but in this case it made the game a lot worse - missing textures, stuttering, sometimes only marginally playable. Many of these issues were addressed over time, but as of the last time we played it was still inferior to the first release. At this point it's fixed enough that I wouldn't reverse my recommendation, just something to be aware of if you'll be playing it on a Mac.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
												1) Essential purchase2) Recommended purchase3) Recommended purchase during a sale4) Not recommended unless heavily discounted5) Not even recommended for Steam game collectorsLooking for something different? This 2005 classic never seemed to get the love it deserved. I've only now gotten to check it out, but its got me hooked from the start. You play as Razputin (voiced by Richard Horvitz, VA of Zim, Billy, Pox, and Orthopox from Invader Zim, Billy and Mandy, and Destroy all Humans respectively) who has snuck away from his circus home to participate in a summer camp for psychics. I hear you thinking: "Psychics? Does that mean puzzles?" To which I say, nay! It means platforming! Literally enter the minds of your victi- er, volunteers, and journey through their mindscapes to learn of their pasts and uncover the horrible truth of the camp. Double Fine isn't known for good gameplay, and while its not the greatest here, I think its deserving of a try.Sounds fun, right? Well it is, but it is not without fault. If you're a stickler for graphics you may be dissapointed in the fairly low budget visuals in this ten year old game, but the atmosphere and mood are set very well. My one complaint are the boss battles, of which you get one every hour or two (at least for the first six hours, which is what I've done at the time of writing). They rely on a simple dodge-wait for weak spot to be exposed-spam attack-repeat formula which is never mixed up very much.The story, I feel, is pretty good. Its nothing spectacular and I can't say much without spoiling, but I'm enjoying it.All in all, check this game out if you have interest in Double Fine, clever/trippy visuals, platformers, or horror movies.NOTE: At some point in the game there's an underwater section where you totally lose control of the camera. Near the end of it the camera bugged so Raz was almost never onscreen. Reset your resolution to 800x600 and die a few times to go back a checkpoint. This fixed it for me.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
												If you’re interested in children, magic, and camps surrounded by tall fences ruled by a dictator, then you are most likely a perverted Nazi. However, If you’re interested in children, magic, and camps surrounded by tall fences ruled by a dictator, then you are a completely normal person and you will enjoy this game with a passionate passion.  In this game you spend most of your time in peoples minds uncovering the lost secrets of their pasts, and while doing so you can collected a bunch of weird chalk drawings that do nothing besides destroy the OCD part of you. These chalk drawings will consume your life, soul, and bodily fluids as at first they are easy to spot giving you a false sense of accomplishment. This easy peasy mindset lasts until the last one where you have to jump across the universe upside down on one leg blindfolded with a firecracker up your butt to get it. Since it’s the last one you have to get it, you're a gamer, OCD and completion run in your veins. Every fiber in your body is saying "go on get the last chalk drawing" but you must resist. IT IS FUTILE. You will never get that last chalk drawing just like how Pluto will never again be a planet. You know Pluto deserves it, he after all was a planet for quite a while. Then one day a bunch of stuck up scientist with their high and mighty positions decided enough was enough. Pluto had it too good for too long. I mean of course he sat on the edge of our solar system, I mean he is just a shy guy you can't take it out on him, and just because he is far away does it not mean he cannot hear us or have feelings. Right now you know his family has out casted him and he is on the verge of suicide. AND WHAT FOR? WHY? EVERYTHING WAS FINE WHEN PLUTO WAS A PLANET. OBAMA WASN'T PRESIDENT, TWINKIES WERE STILL AROUND, AND NELSON MANDELA WAS STILL ALIVE! NELSON MANDELA!!

content:
Posted: December 21, 2011
												Maybe I might be nostalgia tripping, but Psychonauts takes everything good from great games like Banjo-Kazooie and Super Mario 64 and does it much better. It is a very well fleshed out game, if you can get with the very unique artstyle. At any rate it is a much better story telling game, than the aforementioned - going into darker jokes and providing better context for levels with actual plot motivations. It is a great game of it's class, definitely worth trying out. My only gripes, was having to adjust the controls for mouse and keyboard, and that the collectables are flat-alpha-ed planes that are very easy to miss when looking at them from the wrong angles.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2016
												Its a game by Tim Schafer game. If that doesn't sell you, then I guess I'll have to talk about the game.Psychonauts is a platformer that has collectathon elements, powers, and a ranking system, as well as a large hub world. The main chunk of the game and gameplay takes place inside the minds of individuals around the psychics' camp,calling Whispering Rock Psychic Summer Camp.The characters are the best part of this game. This game is amazing in every aspect, but the characters are easily the best part of it. They're quirky, they have their own permanent personalities, they have backstories told through slideshows within that person's level, they are full of life and are portrayed so well by their respective voice actors that you never get the sense that they're people in a room recording lines of dialogue, you get immersed into the world of the psychonauts and the characters slowly have their affect on you. They also teach you valuable life lessons (for instance, control over emotions and saying that you cannot lock it completely away, or you'll explode inside Sasha Nein's marksman training). Honestly, the rest of the game works as well as any other decent 3D paltformer/collectathon, and I can't help but comparing it to Conker's Bad Fur Day, but with fewer curse words. It functions well and would otherwise not stand out, but because of its writing and its characters (and in Psychonaut's case, its art style too. CBFD looked a lot like Banjo & Kazooie). Its powers are neat and the premise is certaintly unique, but the characters really bring this game to life.Double Fine Productions are similar to Vigil games, as many of their games are huge cult classics, that weren't huge at their release, but have over time garnered a huge following. I just hope Double Fine doesn't go the way of Vigil.Overall, I highly recommend it to any 3D platforming fan. Its quirky, it pokes fun and its overall a blast to play. 10/10 from me, Double Fine. I cannot wait for Psychonauts 2 to come out in...2018, supposedly...I just hope its worth the wait and meets expectations

												So this was a game that's been present in my life some way or another for quite some time, to the point where I had 3 copies of it, but only in this year, 2013, did I sit down and dedicate the time to play it. It was better than I could have possibly imagined. Sure, I played the most updated version on the Mac, so it was cleaner looking and probably controlled smoother, but it felt so good for a game that by all rights should have aged a lot more. And the ideas! Oh my. It's unprecedented for a platformer to have convincing reasons for why you can't swim or the MC's uncanny ability to swing from ledge to ledge so elegantly.I felt it struggled along and got pretty frustrating throughout the overlong tutorial section of the game if you don't know what you're doing, but nothing has payed off so much so fast. From the time I entered Lungfishopolis and all the way through the Asylum levels, I just never wanted to stop playing.And I never wanted it to end.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												I just finished the game (59% of the achievements only) and it took 19 hours gameplay. But seriously, i had a lot more fun playing this than i had with other games that took 80 90 hours of my life or more. It has an excellent storyline, interesting and unique characters, and we get many really good laughs. It's not the kind of dumb humour that is spreading everywhere these days, they are very smart jokes. The team that made this game focused on giving you the best experience possible and not make you waste time doing redundant quests. The only time i had to "farm money" was to get an item that would be useful for getting mental cobwebs, helping rank up and get better skills. That took me 10 15 minutes farm max, all the other 18 hours of gameplay was me playing the storyline, and those 15 minutes made me explore a lot of the open world of the game and find some cool stuff.I want psychonauts 2. By crowdfunding they managed to start the project and I will make sure I buy it the moment it is launched. Support quality gaming and not "waste time" gaming. One of the best 20 hours i played in  a game, and i will start again to get all the achievements. Wish you a great day, and thanks for reading this.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
												It had been a while since I played the original PS2 Psychonauts and beat it, possibly a couple years at most. Since I beat it I always had that elusive Rank 101 in mind, having only gotten somewhere around 70-90. Now that I rebought the game I spent a good three consecutive days hunting everything down and getting the ***** to display my name and call me a psychomaster. It got a little frustrating from time to time when I couldn't find the last collectable in a few worlds as they hid in plain sight, but overall... I liked the game. I kinda wished that some of the characters were a little more fleshed out, but for what it is I enjoy it. If you do play this game, don't just rush through it (Unless your goal is to go fast). Instead, take your time and explore the world a few times, you might witness things you didn't expect. Getting all the achievements on Steam really showed me how much of this game I didn't see before. So many new things to do and learn about that my mind was boggled by the sheer amount of stuff. Aim for the highest rank possible, but if you get stuck wondering how to do that *ONE* thing, or where the last collectable is... It isn't necessarily the best idea to get yourself worked up trying to figure it out. Okay, spoilers.SPOILERS TO SOME DEGREE:In the end, it ends up being a bit disappointing that there really isn't any... bonus, for Rank 101. You do get something for rank 100, but not 101. Well, you get the achievement but that's it. Not really worth it in my opinion, but I guess it's the journey that counts.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												This was...a truly wondeful game. Initially, I first came across Physconauts as a picture, one of those random pictures that sometimes appear on google images for some reason or another, intrigued by the oddball style of character design, I looked further into the game, and I was struck by it's capacity to keep you interested. The music for all stages reflected well not only upon the mind of who you were exploring, with each person's mind receiving a unique piece. The character designs are not based on traditional aesthetic values, but still create a diverse cast who, while a great many of them are barely mentioned in the actual plot, are prominent in the many little side affairs that make up camp life (which I found created a realisticness in a place where not too many would expect it). One of the main things I really liked about the game was the exploration factor, in that, the Whispering Rock Psychic Summer Camp proved a vast place to poke, jump, burn, and run around, in fact, a moderate chunk of late game fighting capacity relies on your exploration. Interestingly enough, Psychonauts doesn't rely on overt violence to keep you entertained, although there usually is mental censors of some kind to fight through as minor obstacles in most minds. Instead, you must explore through various places, figuring out how to best get around (One case being how to go up a street without being run over by a bull.) That isn't to say the boss fights aren't challenging. Far from it, as the boss fights I've encountered here, rely not on overt violence, but rather figuring out how to use various psychic powers to exploit the enemy's weakness and win from there. Combine this with amusing dialogue, jokes for all ages, and minor plot arcs which lead one to speculation about real life people based on fictional characters, and many other things which make the Game of Psychonauts a Must Play.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2016
												Its a game by Tim Schafer game. If that doesn't sell you, then I guess I'll have to talk about the game.Psychonauts is a platformer that has collectathon elements, powers, and a ranking system, as well as a large hub world. The main chunk of the game and gameplay takes place inside the minds of individuals around the psychics' camp,calling Whispering Rock Psychic Summer Camp.The characters are the best part of this game. This game is amazing in every aspect, but the characters are easily the best part of it. They're quirky, they have their own permanent personalities, they have backstories told through slideshows within that person's level, they are full of life and are portrayed so well by their respective voice actors that you never get the sense that they're people in a room recording lines of dialogue, you get immersed into the world of the psychonauts and the characters slowly have their affect on you. They also teach you valuable life lessons (for instance, control over emotions and saying that you cannot lock it completely away, or you'll explode inside Sasha Nein's marksman training). Honestly, the rest of the game works as well as any other decent 3D paltformer/collectathon, and I can't help but comparing it to Conker's Bad Fur Day, but with fewer curse words. It functions well and would otherwise not stand out, but because of its writing and its characters (and in Psychonaut's case, its art style too. CBFD looked a lot like Banjo & Kazooie). Its powers are neat and the premise is certaintly unique, but the characters really bring this game to life.Double Fine Productions are similar to Vigil games, as many of their games are huge cult classics, that weren't huge at their release, but have over time garnered a huge following. I just hope Double Fine doesn't go the way of Vigil.Overall, I highly recommend it to any 3D platforming fan. Its quirky, it pokes fun and its overall a blast to play. 10/10 from me, Double Fine. I cannot wait for Psychonauts 2 to come out in...2018, supposedly...I just hope its worth the wait and meets expectations

												Another unusual one.  The game has a good offbeat sense of humor, decent platforming sensibilities, a variety of skills and challenges to use them on, etc.  I'll also rate it up for having some amazingly memorable level designs.  If you've played it, you know immediately the ones I mean; if not, you should.  But the scavenger hunt aspects..  ye gods.  I like exploring and will go a bit out of my way if I see a secret and think I can get to it.  But if you were a completionist and wanted to 100% the game, the quantity of stuff would probably drive you mad.  And if you wanted nothing to do with collecting stuff, the requirement to do so in order to level up would leave you frustrated.All in all, though, quite solid and potentially a lot of fun, despite some frustrating parts.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2012
												I picked up Psychonauts after consistently hearing it referenced as one of the best games ever by people in the games industry. I'm in complete agreement - this is now one of my favorite games. I laughed out loud more often here than in any other game. The level design and variety of art styles is excellent. Gameplay is generally very good and the various psychic powers are fun to play with.Downsides: A few levels and collectible quests can be somewhat frustrating due to precise timing requirements alongside slightly finicky controls (definitely take the time to remap the key/mouse actions as the defaults can be difficult to work with). Also, there comes a point late in the game beyond which you can't go back to the main game area to complete collectible quests or achievements.Two people in our house have put in 150 hours of play on this game. We're playing on a Mac and this version has been smooth and stable with no issues.Update: I was prompted to revisit this review as part of the Steam Autumn Sale 2016. My comments on the game remain valid except for the last paragraph. When we first played the game, it was made as a PC port inside a Mac "wrapper" (Transgaming, I think). This can be problematic for newer, more powerful games, but suited Psychonauts just fine. At some point, however, Double Fine decided to rebuild the game as a native Mac game. This can be a great thing for a game that doesn't work well in a wrapper, but in this case it made the game a lot worse - missing textures, stuttering, sometimes only marginally playable. Many of these issues were addressed over time, but as of the last time we played it was still inferior to the first release. At this point it's fixed enough that I wouldn't reverse my recommendation, just something to be aware of if you'll be playing it on a Mac.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												Full Disclosure: This is one of my favorite games of all time.  I've already purchased a copy for just about everyone I know, and it's always first on my list whenever someone asks for suggestions for what to play next.I love psychonauts, and the Steam version of this game is the definitive version, in my opinion.  The addition of achievements and the graphical enhancements present in this port are fantastic, although i can honestly say you could play any version of this game and have a blast.The design of this game was from a time before "photo-realistic" games rose to prominence, and as such, even the modest graphical upgrades present here aren't really necessary.  can you still pick out where they put their resources? yes.  does it ruin the experience? not in the slightest.Psychonauts is one of the best examples of a genre that is only now beginning to see a resurgence: explorative, collect-a-thon action-platformers with heavy focus on unique worlds and eccentric characters.  These games were prominent in the N64/PSone and PS2/Gamecube era, and the fact that it took until 2015 to secure funding for a sequel is just criminal.long story short, I can't recommend this game highly enough.  While there are some joyless folk who don't like these sorts of games, if you have any fondness for this genre, or just fantastical adventures in general, do yourself a favor and pick this up.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2012
												Psychonauts was created by Tim Schafer (creator or co-creator of Monkey Island 1&2, Day of the Tentacle, Full Throttle, and Grim Fandango). It keeps the storytelling of his previous games while making the leap from adventure to platformer. Raz, a child circus acrobat with psychic powers, breaks into a psychic summer camp to hone his powers. He starts with just acrobatic skills. But as he learns new powers, he can float, bounce to higher areas, light things on fire, shoot laser beams, and much more (in typical Tim Schafer fashion, some powers can be used with humorous results). The story is excellent, the music (composed by Peter McConnell, composer or co-composer of such LucasArts classics as Monkey Island 2, Sam & Max Hit the Road, Day of the Tentacle, and Grim Fandango) is great, the art design is lively and it goes hand in hand with the varied level design, and the characters are fun and well voiced. I can't recommend this game enough. If you haven't played it already, do so now.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												This game is a must have for any fans of the classic Playstation 2 era 3D platformer (Ratchet & Clank, Jak, Ty the Tasmanian Tiger etc.). Much like its peers, Psychonauts features: a cast of funny and interesting characters; beautiful stylised graphics; solid, addicting platforming gameplay and an array of different psychic powers that serve to aid in combat and solve puzzles. The level and world design is fantastic. Each level takes place in the minds of different characters you meet where, as a Psychonaut in training, you must solve their inner turmoils. Every level offers a highly creative, memorable and varied world to explore, where you can collect various items - such as imiginary figments, mental cobwebs and emotional baggage - that upgrade your various powers and health and unlock background stories of the characters. My one criticism is that it suffers a bit from "Collect-a-thon syndrome" and some of the collectables are obscurely placed and have you scouring the map to find the ones you missed. The placement of a couple of the figments is downright evil and I required a guide to locate them but thankfully this was a rare occurance.I thoroughly enjoyed playing and 100% completing Psychonauts as it provided me a real throwback to one of my absolute favourite genres and I feel it holds up well against some of the heavyweights of mid 2000's 3D platforming. For some reason, Psychonauts never sold well when it was released so unfortunately I wasn't aware of this game until a couple of years ago but its Steam release has allowed it to sell a lot better recently and receive the attention it deserves. Psychonauts' recent rennaisance has meant Double Fine are now working on a sequel which I hope can recreate the imagination and creativity that impressed me so much in the original.N.B. I recommend playing with a controller. Mouse and Keyboard controls are alright but a controller is what this game is intended to be played with.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												Psychonauts is a great game. Psychonauts has problems. The positives vastly outweigh the negatives.To get my issues with it out of the way first: - The platforming was difficult for me in parts prompting a lot of trial and error. This sounds like a small point but when the result is continuous repetition to make a  single jump it gets really annoying.- Some enemies were difficult/annoying to fight.- It's sad that you can't bind your powers to more buttons, as tabbing into the menu to swap powers out was just a little too much effort. It was released on the Xbox at the same time so you can see why this was done.Okay now onto the positives:- The story, the environments you find yourself in, the characters and the dialogue are all great. I can't stress this enough. The Steam trailer shows a range of levels of the game but it doesn't capture how excellent the dialogue and delivery is in this story where weird psychic kids go to summer camp.- The graphical style still holds up. For a game over 10 years old, it's not difficult to watch.- Collectibles matter. You level up almost exclusively through collectibles and several of them give you extra things to read/memories to watch. They're all very whimsically created and perfectly integrated into the game.- Some real thought has been put into it. Example: the main character Razputin gives a reason as to why he can't swim (that normal video game limitation). They mention it several times and justify it. Nothing is done arbitrarily, making for a very solid world.- It's a good length. Maybe 8 hours if you rush from place to place. Which you shouldn't do! Talk to as many other characters as possible, the dialogue is wonderful.It's so close to being a game I would say young kids should definitely play (or watch being played). However there are some words I'd call 'not okay' used, and a few moments spring to mind which could be really scary for kids. The comedy gets dark at times. Make your own judgement if you're in that situation.

												Psychonauts is an excellent game. The humor is great, the characters are all interesting, the character designs are all interesting, the different levels are always unique and offer a lot of variety, and the gameplay is mostly solid. There's a few parts of really obnoxious platforming and I think the final boss is a little too easy, considering the level you had to play to get to it. But it's overall fun and it has a lot of replay value.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Psychonauts is a game that stands on its setting. First off, the environment is wonderfully designed. The setting is a summer camp for psychics, and the everyday beauty of nature is distorted by the childlike playfulness ofthe supernatural elements. Boardwalks don't just wind down forest paths, but undulate through space, twisting and turning like something out of a Tim Burton film. The characters are engaging and bizarre, their quirks lovingly detailed, both in appearance and characterization, making everyone unique. There are no generic "background characters" in this game; every character has a backstory, a personality, and their own plot that winds through the narrative of the game. Once you get into the mechanics, however, there are some problems. There are some control issues, and most of the challenge comes, not from the game, but trying to marshal the controls into doing what you want, rather than actually using them to accomplish goals. The only other blemish on the face of this otherwise wonderful game is that the leveling is a bit grind-y, and centered around a series of scavenger hunts, rather than actual gameplay. That said, I feel that a traditional "Combat->XP" system would not have worked with this game, as combat seems to be something that happens when it has to, rather than a constant method of progressing through the game.In short, the play is a little slow and glitchy, but with the engaging setting, you won't mind it much.

												Psychonauts seems like a rather polarizing game in that some people seem to think it's pure gold and some people think it's awful. Which group you'll fall into depends on weather you're the kind person who can allow things like excellent story-telling and charming arti direction excuse a few minor gameplay issues, or if you're the kind of twitching, Ritalin popping, XBox owner who falls into a coma when they go without killing something for five seconds. I'm just going to list out of context some of the things that occur in Psychonauts: a telekinetic bear, a dentist who harvests brains instead of teeth, and a sequence wherein you become a giant  monster and terrorize a society of fish. A game that features all of these things simply cannot be criticized. It's against the law or something. Now so your next course of action should probably be to buy it if you haven't already.

												So this was a game that's been present in my life some way or another for quite some time, to the point where I had 3 copies of it, but only in this year, 2013, did I sit down and dedicate the time to play it. It was better than I could have possibly imagined. Sure, I played the most updated version on the Mac, so it was cleaner looking and probably controlled smoother, but it felt so good for a game that by all rights should have aged a lot more. And the ideas! Oh my. It's unprecedented for a platformer to have convincing reasons for why you can't swim or the MC's uncanny ability to swing from ledge to ledge so elegantly.I felt it struggled along and got pretty frustrating throughout the overlong tutorial section of the game if you don't know what you're doing, but nothing has payed off so much so fast. From the time I entered Lungfishopolis and all the way through the Asylum levels, I just never wanted to stop playing.And I never wanted it to end.

												An excellent  and original game, even by Double Fine standards. Psychonauts has you playing as a 10-year old psychic at a psychic summer camp/government training facility. content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
												If you’re interested in children, magic, and camps surrounded by tall fences ruled by a dictator, then you are most likely a perverted Nazi. However, If you’re interested in children, magic, and camps surrounded by tall fences ruled by a dictator, then you are a completely normal person and you will enjoy this game with a passionate passion.  In this game you spend most of your time in peoples minds uncovering the lost secrets of their pasts, and while doing so you can collected a bunch of weird chalk drawings that do nothing besides destroy the OCD part of you. These chalk drawings will consume your life, soul, and bodily fluids as at first they are easy to spot giving you a false sense of accomplishment. This easy peasy mindset lasts until the last one where you have to jump across the universe upside down on one leg blindfolded with a firecracker up your butt to get it. Since it’s the last one you have to get it, you're a gamer, OCD and completion run in your veins. Every fiber in your body is saying "go on get the last chalk drawing" but you must resist. IT IS FUTILE. You will never get that last chalk drawing just like how Pluto will never again be a planet. You know Pluto deserves it, he after all was a planet for quite a while. Then one day a bunch of stuck up scientist with their high and mighty positions decided enough was enough. Pluto had it too good for too long. I mean of course he sat on the edge of our solar system, I mean he is just a shy guy you can't take it out on him, and just because he is far away does it not mean he cannot hear us or have feelings. Right now you know his family has out casted him and he is on the verge of suicide. AND WHAT FOR? WHY? EVERYTHING WAS FINE WHEN PLUTO WAS A PLANET. OBAMA WASN'T PRESIDENT, TWINKIES WERE STILL AROUND, AND NELSON MANDELA WAS STILL ALIVE! NELSON MANDELA!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
												1) Essential purchase2) Recommended purchase3) Recommended purchase during a sale4) Not recommended unless heavily discounted5) Not even recommended for Steam game collectorsLooking for something different? This 2005 classic never seemed to get the love it deserved. I've only now gotten to check it out, but its got me hooked from the start. You play as Razputin (voiced by Richard Horvitz, VA of Zim, Billy, Pox, and Orthopox from Invader Zim, Billy and Mandy, and Destroy all Humans respectively) who has snuck away from his circus home to participate in a summer camp for psychics. I hear you thinking: "Psychics? Does that mean puzzles?" To which I say, nay! It means platforming! Literally enter the minds of your victi- er, volunteers, and journey through their mindscapes to learn of their pasts and uncover the horrible truth of the camp. Double Fine isn't known for good gameplay, and while its not the greatest here, I think its deserving of a try.Sounds fun, right? Well it is, but it is not without fault. If you're a stickler for graphics you may be dissapointed in the fairly low budget visuals in this ten year old game, but the atmosphere and mood are set very well. My one complaint are the boss battles, of which you get one every hour or two (at least for the first six hours, which is what I've done at the time of writing). They rely on a simple dodge-wait for weak spot to be exposed-spam attack-repeat formula which is never mixed up very much.The story, I feel, is pretty good. Its nothing spectacular and I can't say much without spoiling, but I'm enjoying it.All in all, check this game out if you have interest in Double Fine, clever/trippy visuals, platformers, or horror movies.NOTE: At some point in the game there's an underwater section where you totally lose control of the camera. Near the end of it the camera bugged so Raz was almost never onscreen. Reset your resolution to 800x600 and die a few times to go back a checkpoint. This fixed it for me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												Psychonauts is a rather obscure game, let's start there.You are Raz, a ten-year-old boy with psychic abilities at a summer camp for psychics, and it's your job to become a Psychonaut before your dad picks you up from camp. Sounds bad? Oh, you just wait.Considering this is a 3-D platformer, I'll start at the platforming then. Unless your computer is complete poop and you lag on everything (even Microsoft Word, yes, I know. Soak in the badness) the response you get from jumping, climbing and...uhh...swinging around a pole and then launching yourself. Speaking of jumping, you can double jump.Moving on from jumping on platforms, combat is the other third of this game (the last third is the stages, or 'minds' as they refer to in-game, since your 'levels' are you travelling into other people's minds, most of the time solving an issue they have or getting a power-up). You have your basic 1-2-3 karate chop then force palm combo and your 'palm bomb', a smashing attack when, you guessed it, slam into the ground with your palm (surprising, I know). Now to mention the multiple merit badges you earn to use other abilities, like setting things on fire or turning invisible. This allows you to come up with your own tactics against all enemies, let alone have some fun with non-combat abilities, like Clairvoyance, haha, always a blast to use.(Oh god, that paragraph)Anyway, I've rambled on for long enough. SO LET'S RAMBLE ON MORE!Last, but definately not least, are the minds and psyche of the people you meet. Before I go in-depth and all, Edgar's mind, or Black Velvetopia, is my favourite mind, just so that's out of the way. Each level doesn't feel the same, and every mind has it's own theme, look and way to complete it. For example, in the very first stage, Coach Oleander's mind called 'Basic Braining', has you going through war, which in this case is a massive obstacle course. Might I add, even though this has nothing to do with the levels, is that the dialogue and humour in the game is absolute bliss.Sadly, we come to the bad parts of the game. Uhh, sometimes for me, at least, (even though this only happened to me at the end of the game) the controls will just kinda cut out, leaving you with a falling Raz and a loss of your astral projection layer in the current mind you're in. Or just thrown into a very inconvenient spot. Also, (and also only at the end of the game) the camera direction can be kinda irritating at times. As in, the kind of "WHERE AM I SUPPOSED TO GO?!" camera. This rarely happens and is only for small segments. Finally, enemies that you have no idea how to beat. This is a personal complaint and you can say, maybe a stupid one. I'm talking about enemies, particularly bosses, that you have no idea how to beat and you're left with something kicking your♥♥♥♥♥and there's nothing you can do about it. This is the biggest complaint here, and you can make a counterarguement stating how that this is just learning the game. Yeah, it is, but without a walkthrough, it can be irritating at times.Now, before I go on about more tiny aspects, I'm gonna wrap up this review. This game is a beutiful blend of humour, tight controls, variety and lovable characters that combinates into the best platformer I have ever played, heck, it's definately my favourite PC game to date! Yes, I like it that much. So, unless it's completely obvious, do I like this game or not?Well of coarse I like this game! I recommend everyone with a sense of humour and a love for indie games. From me, an average gamer who just completed this game for the first time, gives this game a 9/10. It's amazing, easy to pick up and play, and hilarious to experience.~Horris

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												A rare gem of a game, Psychonauts uses a sharp sense of humour and self mockery (similar to many Schafer games) to draw you in to an engaging story, filled with superbly absurd characters (all perfectly voice acted) and situations.The gameplay itself is addictingly easy and fun, but the game sets itself apart from other platformers with its diverse level design, reinventing itself with each new stage, while keeping a simple set of basic mechanics to navigate the often outlandish and ridiculous world.With each stage based inside a person's mind, Psychonauts is Burton-esque in its disregard for conventional standards, instead creating a dreamlike mish-mash of wild colors and music.  (The soundtrack really is worth it, you'll find yourself humming the various themes for hours after finishing a stage.)Though the graphics are dated, the gameplay and atmosphere is timeless, making this game a must-play for anyone who loves double-fine, james willems, or just good plain fun.  While it's undoubtedly worth the full price, this game often does go on sale for one dollar, so consider waiting for that.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2012
												Okay, so this is a really old game. Not as old as one would expect "old" to mean, but it was from the console generation involving the Gamecube.I do believe this surpasses many modern games in quality and enjoyability. Whilst there are the typical mistakes and glitches you can find in any platform/adventure game (to do with jumping, climbing and such), they have been nothing more than a minor inconveniance. Visual quality of the game is astounding. Whilst the game doesn't have the billions of polygons and pixels in textures you can find in newer games, they lip-synching is nearly always spot-on. That's a major plus for me. It makes the game seem all that more real.The story and level design are brilliant, too. You can expect a lot of dark humour as you travel through the minds of others in an attempt to get to the bottom of a devious plot. You'll have fun travelling, too. The different minds you visit provide a variety of levels. Pick it up and give it a try!

content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
												It had been a while since I played the original PS2 Psychonauts and beat it, possibly a couple years at most. Since I beat it I always had that elusive Rank 101 in mind, having only gotten somewhere around 70-90. Now that I rebought the game I spent a good three consecutive days hunting everything down and getting the ***** to display my name and call me a psychomaster. It got a little frustrating from time to time when I couldn't find the last collectable in a few worlds as they hid in plain sight, but overall... I liked the game. I kinda wished that some of the characters were a little more fleshed out, but for what it is I enjoy it. If you do play this game, don't just rush through it (Unless your goal is to go fast). Instead, take your time and explore the world a few times, you might witness things you didn't expect. Getting all the achievements on Steam really showed me how much of this game I didn't see before. So many new things to do and learn about that my mind was boggled by the sheer amount of stuff. Aim for the highest rank possible, but if you get stuck wondering how to do that *ONE* thing, or where the last collectable is... It isn't necessarily the best idea to get yourself worked up trying to figure it out. Okay, spoilers.SPOILERS TO SOME DEGREE:In the end, it ends up being a bit disappointing that there really isn't any... bonus, for Rank 101. You do get something for rank 100, but not 101. Well, you get the achievement but that's it. Not really worth it in my opinion, but I guess it's the journey that counts.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												Another unusual one.  The game has a good offbeat sense of humor, decent platforming sensibilities, a variety of skills and challenges to use them on, etc.  I'll also rate it up for having some amazingly memorable level designs.  If you've played it, you know immediately the ones I mean; if not, you should.  But the scavenger hunt aspects..  ye gods.  I like exploring and will go a bit out of my way if I see a secret and think I can get to it.  But if you were a completionist and wanted to 100% the game, the quantity of stuff would probably drive you mad.  And if you wanted nothing to do with collecting stuff, the requirement to do so in order to level up would leave you frustrated.All in all, though, quite solid and potentially a lot of fun, despite some frustrating parts.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2013
												Psychonauts is a classic. While often described as a platformer it really is just another way for Tim Schaeffer to tell a story as he always has, this time through a hub world action platformer rather than a point-and-click adventure. As confident and compelling protagonist Raz you explore the minds of others to learn more about yourself all the while building and adding new psychic powers to your repertoire. If you like action and adventure with some platforming thrown in Psychonauts will gladly scratch that itch and have you coming back for more. With full controller support and achievements this is a must own for any Steam gamer.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												Full Disclosure: This is one of my favorite games of all time.  I've already purchased a copy for just about everyone I know, and it's always first on my list whenever someone asks for suggestions for what to play next.I love psychonauts, and the Steam version of this game is the definitive version, in my opinion.  The addition of achievements and the graphical enhancements present in this port are fantastic, although i can honestly say you could play any version of this game and have a blast.The design of this game was from a time before "photo-realistic" games rose to prominence, and as such, even the modest graphical upgrades present here aren't really necessary.  can you still pick out where they put their resources? yes.  does it ruin the experience? not in the slightest.Psychonauts is one of the best examples of a genre that is only now beginning to see a resurgence: explorative, collect-a-thon action-platformers with heavy focus on unique worlds and eccentric characters.  These games were prominent in the N64/PSone and PS2/Gamecube era, and the fact that it took until 2015 to secure funding for a sequel is just criminal.long story short, I can't recommend this game highly enough.  While there are some joyless folk who don't like these sorts of games, if you have any fondness for this genre, or just fantastical adventures in general, do yourself a favor and pick this up.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												This game is a must have for any fans of the classic Playstation 2 era 3D platformer (Ratchet & Clank, Jak, Ty the Tasmanian Tiger etc.). Much like its peers, Psychonauts features: a cast of funny and interesting characters; beautiful stylised graphics; solid, addicting platforming gameplay and an array of different psychic powers that serve to aid in combat and solve puzzles. The level and world design is fantastic. Each level takes place in the minds of different characters you meet where, as a Psychonaut in training, you must solve their inner turmoils. Every level offers a highly creative, memorable and varied world to explore, where you can collect various items - such as imiginary figments, mental cobwebs and emotional baggage - that upgrade your various powers and health and unlock background stories of the characters. My one criticism is that it suffers a bit from "Collect-a-thon syndrome" and some of the collectables are obscurely placed and have you scouring the map to find the ones you missed. The placement of a couple of the figments is downright evil and I required a guide to locate them but thankfully this was a rare occurance.I thoroughly enjoyed playing and 100% completing Psychonauts as it provided me a real throwback to one of my absolute favourite genres and I feel it holds up well against some of the heavyweights of mid 2000's 3D platforming. For some reason, Psychonauts never sold well when it was released so unfortunately I wasn't aware of this game until a couple of years ago but its Steam release has allowed it to sell a lot better recently and receive the attention it deserves. Psychonauts' recent rennaisance has meant Double Fine are now working on a sequel which I hope can recreate the imagination and creativity that impressed me so much in the original.N.B. I recommend playing with a controller. Mouse and Keyboard controls are alright but a controller is what this game is intended to be played with.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2012
												Psychonauts was created by Tim Schafer (creator or co-creator of Monkey Island 1&2, Day of the Tentacle, Full Throttle, and Grim Fandango). It keeps the storytelling of his previous games while making the leap from adventure to platformer. Raz, a child circus acrobat with psychic powers, breaks into a psychic summer camp to hone his powers. He starts with just acrobatic skills. But as he learns new powers, he can float, bounce to higher areas, light things on fire, shoot laser beams, and much more (in typical Tim Schafer fashion, some powers can be used with humorous results). The story is excellent, the music (composed by Peter McConnell, composer or co-composer of such LucasArts classics as Monkey Island 2, Sam & Max Hit the Road, Day of the Tentacle, and Grim Fandango) is great, the art design is lively and it goes hand in hand with the varied level design, and the characters are fun and well voiced. I can't recommend this game enough. If you haven't played it already, do so now.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												With a cast of unique and memorable characters, great voice-acting and vivid level designs, this game is fun to both play and watch. Being partially a member of the platformer genre, the "psychic levels" don't necessarily play nice with the mouse-look controls and a convoluted, unnecessary levelling mechanic had me scrounging aroud arrowheads, to purchase psy-cores to return to Ford's Sanctuary to combine with psi-cards to create psi-markers... Or I guess you could just go around and collect figments to level much faster and simpler without getting side-tracked from the main campaign. The control scheme is also not obvious if you leave the game alone for a while after the tutorial. At one point, I pulled up a walkthrough to figure out how to open my backpack! Felt like an idiot when I saw how close I was to doing it.While I'm still not finished and my opinion of the game may change, its problems have not increased since the beginning but its strengths have gotten better as I unlock new abilities. I still worry about how much the difficulty will ramp up as it's not clear how much success I have is due to pressing the correct buttons and how much is due to forgiving, kid-friendly levels. The first boss was appropriately challenging though so I'm not too worried.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												One of the most original takes on an "action/adventure game" I have ever played. And it's funny.Boiled down to its component pieces, Psychonauts is a platformer that involves running, jumping, swinging, climbing, exploring, punching, and powering-up your abilities.Beyond that, it's a funny, highly entertaining, engaging, and rewarding game that could really do with a sequel. The characters and story have enough twists to keep you interested, the comedy provides light relief before, during, and after the game's challenges appear, there are plenty of treasure hunts and side-missions to keep you busy, and the flavour of the gameplay changes often enough to pique your interest. Did I mention the humour?

content:
Posted: March 6
★★★★☆I'll be honest, this game didn't quite click with me, but I'd still recommend it to anyone. For starters, the game is developped by a studio that was never particulary big and got a lot of public attention because of this game. Rightfully so, because the world-, game- and characterdesigns of this game are extremely memorable to say the least. It has something like the Tim Burton movie 'Nightmare on Christmas' but colorful. It has a good amount of humor (that did not always click with me) and a charm that will make a lot of people make in love with it. The devs spent a lot of money on spoken dialogue and designing the world -some parts you even don't have to see to finish the game - which I can only appreciate and applaud to.It also isn't a run-of-the-mill platformer, as you don't always progress over a landscape by running from start to finish, but instead run around and replace objects, like delivering a letter to a character. It's not revolutionary at all, but it will pull the player into the world because it requires attention/thinking.For me, that caused some pacing issues. At times it felt like I was on a roll, at other times it felt like I got stuck only because I didn't know I could interact with a particulary object. I also exprienced a drag after the first level, as I found myself wandering almost aimlessly in the forest, collecting feathers and talking to characters about nonsenses. It was pretty straight forward before, but than suddenly it asked me to explore on my own.Some players might appriciate this, but to me this was kind of jarring.However, in a lot of cases the player is covered with good intell that you can collect at anytime to use 'bacon' to 'phone call' your superior in the game to simply ask to what you should do. All this is voice-acted and well-done.Jarring is also the word I would use for the crazy amount of collectibles. I tried to collect them all early game, but I soon felt distracted by them and got eventually bored with it since there are sometimes over 200 of them in 1 level. So achievement hunters beware: this might feel like a boring job to you.I also didn't like the voice acting that often, since a good amount of characters in the game have a childish high-pitch voice. This was extremely grindy in the theater level and especially annoying in one of the last levels where a kid would yell every 2 seconds because some enemy was hitting him. In this same frustrating sequence, you had to get to him asap by performing some divers platforming. I mistake, and you fall down, unable to get to the kid in time, forcing you to redo the same 2-5 minutes. Luckily, the is the only part of the game where I thought the game truly wasn't fun to play.Having said that, I generally think that level design isn't that great. It's no Mario game, but it does have some small issues. Oddly enough I felt like I cheated through some parts as I was using the 'ball jump' to get to higher places, skipping some ladders along the way. It was like the level designers had other intentions, before they knew about what the actual control scheme would really look like. Oh, on a side note: in the last level the double jump didn't always work for me, which was in this case infuriating.It's right if you'd say that the above points sounds like nitpicks to you, but to me they were more in my way of enjoyment of the game than I wanted it to be. In the end, this game felt like it wasn't really for me. However, I can tell it's a nicely polished game with some well-thought out parts in it, that I can recomment this to anybody. Pick it up during a Steam Sale, since often times it's discounted for 1 buck. That's a steal!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												I have a love-hate relationship with developer of Psychonauts, Double Fine. They have this incredible talent to create the most intriguing concepts and amazing characters for their games. Honestly, it's why I keep playing them. The previous Double Fine projects I had played were point-and-click adventures, so I was looking forward to experiencing their take on a different genre. I wasn't disappointed, as Psychonauts has to be one of their best games--even 11 years after its original release.Don't get me wrong, Double Fine's other games are great. They all have solid stories and gameplay, and dialogue is practically the developer's niche. However, there's one problem I have with their formula that seems to carry over into each of their games, and that's the ridiculously difficult puzzles. You can call me stupid if you like, but I have the hardest time with Double Fine's brain teasers--I've yet to play one of their games without a guide. Psychonauts doesn't quite suffer as badly in this respect, because the game's focus leans toward platforming. That being said, there were still many times I had look up where to go or what to do, because any hints I was given were so vague. Granted, a lot of this complaint is formed by my own impatience, but the problem is still there regardless of how my own shortcomings blows it up. With that gripe out of the way, there's plenty of room for a shower of praise, because Psychonauts is amazing. It reminded of a time when I was a kid playing Ratchet & Clank on my now broken PS2. It has this amazing sense of humor that can have you laughing out loud at one moment and face-palming the next. I love experiencing these jokes and thinking how I never would have caught on to them in 2005. The characters have to be some of the most varied I've ever seen. The peculiar character models probably helps with that, but it's also how each individual's quirks and intricacies shine through the dialogue. Double Fine knows how to make unique characters, and I love it. However, while all the voices were great there were segments where they wouldn't shut up while you were performing some task, and it got aggravating.On that note, the music did the same thing on occasion. It sucks when you're stuck trying to figure out a puzzle and there's some obnoxious music blaring in your ears. Besides that the music was fine. It wasn't anything noteworthy such as in Grim Fandango, unfortunately. Finally, the gameplay is tight and easy to acclimate to. Progressing through the game will land you new abilities, though I tended to stick to a chosen three. What's nice is you can switch any of them out on the fly, meaning you can instantly adapt to any situation. The platforming is spot on as well. I had a blast jumping, floating and sliding around the levels. Sometimes there were some awkward designs that caused me some frustration but nothing to hurt my experience too badly. There's also a surplus of collectibles to find and turn in. Doing so gives you bonuses and even some insight into some of the characters' backstories. I can see myself someday returning to Psychonauts to collect everything I missed. I can't stop playing Double Fine games. My first was Broken Age, which was a severe disappointment (because of the second half). Then I gave Grim Fandango a try, and I loved it. Now I've played Psychonauts, and I'm incredibly glad I did. I wish I'd experienced as a kid, but it's better late than never. Seriously, if you enjoy a platformer adventure with a colorful cast and great gameplay, then look no farther than Psychonauts.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												It's the Psychonauts that you've always known and loved, complete with the original premise, pleasing design and legitimately funny humour. Laugh as you play the game. Cry as you attempt to collect all the figments.Some minor changes from the Xbox version include the infamous Meat Circus level having its difficulty lowered (you now have infinite lives, though I still advise staying away from children for at least 48 hours afterwards as your murderous impulses lower), some minor graphical glitches and a keyboard and mouse control scheme that, while functional, doesn't really compare to using a gamepad. I advise using one as this game has native support, though it doesn't show the bindings. It's also worth noting that this game has full widescreen support (which includes the FMVs) and supports all the resolutions you think it would. It also has achievements, if you're into that. Freak.While not about to be remembered as a fantastic, ♥♥♥♥♥♥-inducing port, the source game is enough to make you cream yourself on its own merit. Play it! Or don't. I'm not about to steal your brain if you don't listen to me.

Posted: September 21, 2015
												One of the greatest games of all time. Buy it now and enjoy it for the rest of your life.Yeah, it's that good. I love this game. Gaming perfection? Pretty much.Pros:- Great levels. Some of the most unique and great levels in video game history- Collection items are a blast. I am not a fan of collecting items, but this game makes it so much fun.- Hilarious story and characters. Wow, games rarely are this funny. It's amazing- Pure 100% joy and happiness. Games should make us smile, laugh, and enjoy the experience. This game does that X10.- Countless hidden secrets and gems. If you just play through without trying everything, you are missing out. Hint: Use Clairvoyance on everyone and everything. Always a laugh.- Looks great in HD. Works with wired Xbox 360 controller. Looks like it came out recently despite being 10 years old.Cons:- Meat Circus is still hard, even patched to be easier. I beat the PS2 version and it was a lot harder. Still, kind of annoying. Seriously, though it's nothing significant. 10/10100/100Buy it now.  Pledge your money to a sequel.
