												I love this game, it's a shame I didn't find it until about 3 years ago. The story and characters are excellent, I love the level design (the most interesting I've seen in a game apart from some of the DmC(reboot) and they were enhanced by the story of every character) and the ♥♥♥♥ed up things that are in it. The gameplay is really good, the back stories for most characters were really interesting and loved that even if it looks for kids it contains really mature subjects.Raaz was one of the most relatable characters, found things weird and annoying when you did but at same time he was having the time of his life (like I did). The only criticism I have with the game is the camera, it's a 2005 so... I can forgive it but still it is annoying at some parts.For me is an excellent game and it deserves a 9/10 :).SPOILER ALERT!!!Loved the asylum part, specially the Milkman part haha one of the best levels I've played in any game. Also that easter egg with Clem and Crystal in the roof top... WTF?..  also that one Sasha made me pretty uneasy and then I saw the memories...♥♥♥♥♥♥..

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8, 2016
												One of the best platform/adventure games I've ever played. Reminded me a lot of the awesome Rare days of Banjo-Kazooie, Conker and Donkey Kong 64. I'm not saying this game is like those, it certainly has the qualities of a platform game; jumping puzzles, collectibles, abilities that help you overcome new obstacles. But it executes those things in a way that is different from those other games.The game deals with psychic powers and travelling through the minds and dreams of others. You will get different psychic powers, some of which are awesome to use all the time, that will let you access different areas and overcome different enemies while travelling throuh the minds of people and dealing with their fears and issues which will transform into monsters that you will have to defeat.The story is hilarious, the characters are so cool and memorable, the Milkman comes to mind. The art style is pretty freaky, everything looks otherwordly and rightly so, as you will mostly be travelling the dreams inside the minds of your friends.I truly recommend this game to anyone who likes adventure games and weird, unique wrolds with very funny stories and characters.Do play with a controller, it is much more enjoyable in this game to do so.

content:
Posted: January 5
												I highly recommend psychonauts to anyone who is nostalgic for the 3rd person platformers of the 2000s.PROS:Every level is unique and well designed, and each introduces different gameplay mechanics, so the game never gets boring. The game is genuinely funny.It makes you care about the characters by making you help them through their problems, and showing you how they got those problems.Unique powers that are used in many different situations.It has puns.CONS:The upgrades didn't feel neccesary to complete the game.Since I didn't feel like the upgrades were neccesary I didn't try to get any of the collectibles, except for ones that added more to the story or raised my health bar.One level had alot of unskippable cutscenes that I had to watch multiple times.The final level seemed to hard, but the final boss felt really easy.But the pros do really outway the cons in this game, and I hope you check it out.P.S If ten dollars seems like too much to you, just wait for it to be ninety nine cents in every steam sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												This game has been on my radar ever since 2005, when it was released and I read the rave review my favorite video game magazine gave it. It seemed to have all these elements that were really up my alley - great humour, intersting characters and the crazy fun idea that you have to explore the mind of a bizarre band of misfits... So what took me 11 year until I finally got to play it? Well, that fact that it was a platformer. Somehow I got this image in my head, how all the fun that was promised to me was constantly interupted by awkward and repetitive jumping on tree branches and floating platforms... Boy, was I in for a surprise!... Of course the surprise wasn't about the humour, characters or the crazy ideas of the game... this is all in the package. The surprise was how ridiculously good the platforming is! From the moment you start the game the controls just fell so right... so responsive (provided you play with gamepad)! It's simply fun to traverse and explore the world. Actually this is the second ever game where I feel like finding all the collectibles (the first one being Trine) and belive me they are not in small numbers. To be honest the camera sometimes can get in your way, but for a 3d platformer that has to be expected.The other thing that really surprised me was how well the game has aged. I actually love playing the classics and have no problem going way back to the early 90s. But Psychonauts dosn't feel like an old game at all. It could have been released this year and I would feel like it needs to change a single thing. Also the great artstyle really helps it to stand the test of time. The only remark beeing that the cutscenes are noticeably lower res.So don't be like me, do yourself a favoir and don't wait another 11 year to play this great game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												I just finished this game a day ago and it's now easily one of my top ten favorite games.It has some warts, no doubt. The PC and Mac ports are a little finicky (at the time of this writing it's crashed a total of 8 times on me, and I had to unbind the camera controls on my controller because it kept pointing the camera directly up), the camera can be obnoxious and the final level is stupidly frustrating, but because of how amazing the rest of the game is you can easily forgive that.There's so much depth in the story and characters (told through a giant collect-a-thon, but that's mid '00's games for you) that it's easy to get lost in the strange world that Psychonauts takes place in. You'll drive yourself (aptly) insane trying to find all the figments just for that extra little morsel of story, and then you'll go back through the game AGAIN and pick up on little story hints that you missed the first time.The writing is excellent, thanks to Eric Wolpaw and Tim Schafer (say what you will about him, he at least knows how to write good dialogue), the gameplay holds up, and the characters are interesting and fun to interact with. If you missed out on playing this, this is a must-have.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												Psychonauts... what can I say? It's a single-player platformer. You are Razputin (commonly known as "Raz") and you are a wanna-be Psychonaut! You take a summer camp which are for Psycadets to learn about being a Psychonaut, but no one really is interested in all this mojo stuff... except for you! You are very excited and pumped to be in this summer camp. You are living your cadet life normally until you dig deeper in the story and learn secrets about other people. The game has some RPG elements to it, with dialogues, leveling up system (kind of), etc. This game can get pretty bizarre after you've played it for some while. It gets REALLY weird, because you are a psychic and things are strange inside people's minds; especially if they're a MADMAN. Verdict: 7.5/10 stars. Just get it. It's worth it if you like a good platformer.

												Loved this. Awesome storyline, great environment, lots of fun stuff to collect. It's worth noting (if you're into achievements) that many of them are entirely missable, also that it goes dark part way through the game making finding stuff outside much harder and there is no free roaming after you finish the game so you will be wanting to grab everything as you go along. content:
Posted: June 23, 2012
												The most creative game I have ever played.  I absolutely loved this game for many different reasons but I think my main readon for loving it is that it creates a rich and vibrant world for you to explore and investigate.  The characters are all distinguishable and I mean for god's sake the main evil guy is absolutely hilarious.  A dentist who removes brains I mean I wish I could come up with that.  There a about nine different psychic abilities that you get in the game and each one just as important as the others at some point.  Some you use more than others but each a joy to use.  The envirmonments are mainly different characters imaginations and each one is so unique making the experience believable and intriguing.  Environments outside the mind are also well done but the creativity shines when you enter a persons mind to battle their demons.  All in all the humor, story, environments, and gameplay are all fantastic.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2011
												Psychonauts is one of my favorite games of all time, and I'm glad it has finally come to Mac (and gotten Steam achievements)! This isn't the best platformer ever, but it's not bad. Combined with the various psychic powers you get throughout the game, it makes for a lot of fun. It's not super difficult most of the way through. (The final level is notoriously difficult, but supposedly they toned its difficulty back with the Mac release; I don't know yet, I haven't made it that far since the Mac release came out.)The graphics are a little dated now, but the art styles are very fun. Every mind is different with its own unique styles. It's also a very well-written game, story-wise. Be sure to take time to go through it; they've put in all sorts of little details, including ones I didn't even realize were in there until I had to go hunting for them from the achievements!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												A brilliant platformer that really surprised me. I had played Psychonauts briefly on PS2 but picked it up on Steam sale with the intentions of finishing it someday. After I started the game, I couldn't stop playing! The writing in Psychonauts is what sets it apart but the tight controls, varied level designs, and artwork are all great too. As you learn new psychic abilities, you'll use them to reach new areas but it doesn't feel like a locked off area akin to a Metroid or Zelda game. Anyone with an interest in how the world looks to other people and battles of the mind would love this game and it's worth the retail price easily!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2012
												Psychonauts is a PS2-era action platformer. Developed by Double Fine and originally published by Majesco, it was released in 2005 for the Xbox, and 2006 for the PC and Playstation 2.It was reviewed well, but sold poorly, and has garnered a cult following. It's not an old game, but a lot has changed since it came out. Let's see how it holds up today.It stars the young wanna-be "Psychonaut" Razputin, commonly referred to as "Raz." Razputin sneaks into a camp for gifted children, (I know what you're thinking, and no. Not that kind. These kids have mind powers. Like, burning things. With their minds!) but is caught by the, uh, camp counselors, I guess. One of them looks like Resetti. Anyway, they want to send Raz home, but are unable to contact his parents. So they let him stay. And things start to get weird. Like, kids having their brains removed and walking around like zombies weird.The plot is good enough, won't win any awards, but it is charming and well written. The creativity behind the game is exceptional. Levels all take place in people's heads. Literally. Raz gets sucked into their brain through a tiny door. It's basically Extreme Makeover: Therapy Edition. You help people with their mental health, in the most fun way possible. No two levels are the same, just like people's minds. And just like the levels, the characters are great. Highlights include: A paranoid milkman, a heartbroken luchadore, a descendant of Napoleon with split-personality disorder, and a friendly psychic mutant angler-fish. Every character's level reflects their personality, and are all fun, different, and interesting.There's not much more to be said about Psychonauts without giving spoilers. This is truly one of those games that you are better off jumping in head first with reckless abandon. Don't look anything up about this game. You'll thank me later. I guarantee it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
Product received for free
												This game is probably one of the best games I've ever played. It'll definitely be a favorite of mine for a long time, and I'm looking forward to the upcoming sequel.The game has a great art style, a great story, and an outstanding soundtrack. I especially love how the game makes clever use of symbolism in some of the levels such as a character living in a literally twisted reality or another character who is literally fighting a battle in his mind.However, it's not perfect. Controls can be a little clunky, especially when it comes to combat. On top of this, Psychonauts has plenty of platforming. Obviously, this isn't bad in and of itself. However, most platformers tend to follow one rule of thumb and it's this: Sooner or later, the difficulty will reach rage-inducing levels. Psychonauts is no exception.Also, some of the bosses can be a little rough. I mean, obviously. It's a boss fight, it's supposed to be rough. What I mean is, they sometimes don't make much sense. Like how some bosses seem to be immune to lasers, yet the very same boss's weakness is the typical melee attack.But don't let these things repel you from purchashing this title. It's a solid game and a wonderful gaming experience. Just be prepared to be a little patient with it as you draw nearer to the end.Also, if you're a completionist, make sure to use multiple save slots. The game has a "Point of no return." It does the Zelda thing where you can't save after the final boss, but it automatically saves after you cross this "point of no return." And that means that if you used only one save slot (like I did,) then you're stranded! You can't go back and get those achievements that you missed unless you start another playthrough.Then again, if you love the game as much as I did, you won't necessarily object to the idea of a second playthrough.

I absolutely loved this game for many different reasons but I think my main readon for loving it is that it creates a rich and vibrant world for you to explore and investigate.  The characters are all distinguishable and I mean for god's sake the main evil guy is absolutely hilarious.  A dentist who removes brains I mean I wish I could come up with that.  There a about nine different psychic abilities that you get in the game and each one just as important as the others at some point.  Some you use more than others but each a joy to use. Environments outside the mind are also well done but the creativity shines when you enter a persons mind to battle their demons.  All in all the humor, story, environments, and gameplay are all fantastic.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2011
												Psychonauts is one of my favorite games of all time, and I'm glad it has finally come to Mac (and gotten Steam achievements)! This isn't the best platformer ever, but it's not bad. Combined with the various psychic powers you get throughout the game, it makes for a lot of fun. It's not super difficult most of the way through. (The final level is notoriously difficult, but supposedly they toned its difficulty back with the Mac release; I don't know yet, I haven't made it that far since the Mac release came out.)The graphics are a little dated now, but the art styles are very fun. Every mind is different with its own unique styles. It's also a very well-written game, story-wise. Be sure to take time to go through it; they've put in all sorts of little details, including ones I didn't even realize were in there until I had to go hunting for them from the achievements!

content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												Psychonauts... what can I say? It's a single-player platformer. You are Razputin (commonly known as "Raz") and you are a wanna-be Psychonaut! You take a summer camp which are for Psycadets to learn about being a Psychonaut, but no one really is interested in all this mojo stuff... except for you! You are very excited and pumped to be in this summer camp. You are living your cadet life normally until you dig deeper in the story and learn secrets about other people. The game has some RPG elements to it, with dialogues, leveling up system (kind of), etc. This game can get pretty bizarre after you've played it for some while. It gets REALLY weird, because you are a psychic and things are strange inside people's minds; especially if they're a MADMAN. Verdict: 7.5/10 stars. Just get it. It's worth it if you like a good platformer.

												I highly recommend psychonauts to anyone who is nostalgic for the 3rd person platformers of the 2000s.PROS:Every level is unique and well designed, and each introduces different gameplay mechanics, so the game never gets boring. The game is genuinely funny.It makes you care about the characters by making you help them through their problems, and showing you how they got those problems.Unique powers that are used in many different situations.It has puns.CONS:The upgrades didn't feel neccesary to complete the game.Since I didn't feel like the upgrades were neccesary I didn't try to get any of the collectibles, except for ones that added more to the story or raised my health bar.One level had alot of unskippable cutscenes that I had to watch multiple times.The final level seemed to hard, but the final boss felt really easy.But the pros do really outway the cons in this game, and I hope you check it out.P.S If ten dollars seems like too much to you, just wait for it to be ninety nine cents in every steam sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												This game has been on my radar ever since 2005, when it was released and I read the rave review my favorite video game magazine gave it. It seemed to have all these elements that were really up my alley - great humour, intersting characters and the crazy fun idea that you have to explore the mind of a bizarre band of misfits... So what took me 11 year until I finally got to play it? Well, that fact that it was a platformer. Somehow I got this image in my head, how all the fun that was promised to me was constantly interupted by awkward and repetitive jumping on tree branches and floating platforms... Boy, was I in for a surprise!... Of course the surprise wasn't about the humour, characters or the crazy ideas of the game... this is all in the package. The surprise was how ridiculously good the platforming is! From the moment you start the game the controls just fell so right... so responsive (provided you play with gamepad)! It's simply fun to traverse and explore the world. Actually this is the second ever game where I feel like finding all the collectibles (the first one being Trine) and belive me they are not in small numbers. To be honest the camera sometimes can get in your way, but for a 3d platformer that has to be expected.The other thing that really surprised me was how well the game has aged. I actually love playing the classics and have no problem going way back to the early 90s. But Psychonauts dosn't feel like an old game at all. It could have been released this year and I would feel like it needs to change a single thing. Also the great artstyle really helps it to stand the test of time. The only remark beeing that the cutscenes are noticeably lower res.So don't be like me, do yourself a favoir and don't wait another 11 year to play this great game.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												Psychonauts is a great game. Psychonauts has problems. The positives vastly outweigh the negatives.To get my issues with it out of the way first: - The platforming was difficult for me in parts prompting a lot of trial and error. This sounds like a small point but when the result is continuous repetition to make a  single jump it gets really annoying.- Some enemies were difficult/annoying to fight.- It's sad that you can't bind your powers to more buttons, as tabbing into the menu to swap powers out was just a little too much effort. It was released on the Xbox at the same time so you can see why this was done.Okay now onto the positives:- The story, the environments you find yourself in, the characters and the dialogue are all great. I can't stress this enough. The Steam trailer shows a range of levels of the game but it doesn't capture how excellent the dialogue and delivery is in this story where weird psychic kids go to summer camp.- The graphical style still holds up. For a game over 10 years old, it's not difficult to watch.- Collectibles matter. You level up almost exclusively through collectibles and several of them give you extra things to read/memories to watch. They're all very whimsically created and perfectly integrated into the game.- Some real thought has been put into it. Example: the main character Razputin gives a reason as to why he can't swim (that normal video game limitation). They mention it several times and justify it. Nothing is done arbitrarily, making for a very solid world.- It's a good length. Maybe 8 hours if you rush from place to place. Which you shouldn't do! Talk to as many other characters as possible, the dialogue is wonderful.It's so close to being a game I would say young kids should definitely play (or watch being played). However there are some words I'd call 'not okay' used, and a few moments spring to mind which could be really scary for kids. The comedy gets dark at times. Make your own judgement if you're in that situation.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2015
												Progression is rather linear, but it is actually fun. Everything about the game is unique, from the art style to most of the abilities to the characters to the dialogue. Black Velvetopia especially is a beautiful piece of art. Wonderful game all around but is also has minor annoyances. For example, the mouse and keyboard combination takes getting used too and some parts of the game are down right infuriating with them. Small parts of stages have awful design (I'm looking at the Waterloo mainly). Found myself exploiting the hell out of levitation. Still, I highly recommend this game. NOTE: If you are using Windows 7, I recommend going to Psychonauts.exe > Properties and sticking it in Compatibility mode with Windows 95. The game up until Gloria's Theater ran fine, but then the graphics started messing up and the fps hit the fan. Doing the above fixed it and I encounter no issues past that.

content:
Posted: January 9
												A Tim Schafer classic from back in 2005, Psychonauts still holds up in 2017. It's a surreal, hilarious romp through a fascinating world (both real and mental) with well fleshed-out characters and a solid story. At its core, the game is a platformer, also featuring many collectibles which become available once progression unlocks new abilities and items. Gameplay is tight and satisfying, and at around 10 to 12 hours the campaign doesn't wear out its welcome. With news of Psychonauts 2 being successfully crowdfunded, I'm excited to see how Double Fine can update this winning formula with new technology.

Posted: December 27, 2014
												This is one of my all time favorite games and you should play it. I don't know what else to write so here is a recipe for the only thing I know of that is almost as good as this game INGREDIENTS:1 cup powdered sugar1/2 cup creamy peanut butter2 small boxes of instant vanilla pudding (home made pudding is better but instant is far easier) 1 (9-inch) gram cracker pie crust 2 cups whipped creamSlightly adapted from The Amish CookDIRECTIONS:in one bowl make puddingin an other bowl mix peanut butter and powdered sugar until you have a bowl of little peanut butter nuggets.After pudding is somewhat cool you can start to assemble the pie.Add half the peanut butter nuggets to the bottom of the pie shell. Top with pudding. Add half the remaining peanut butter nuggets to the top of the pudding.Top with whipped cream and remaining peanut butter nuggets.Let the pie cool in the refrigerator for at least 2 hours to set up before cutting.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												Platform games come in many shapes and sizes. There are the big-name platforming mainstays, such as Mario and Sonic, that rely on their own brand of rules and obstacles to overcome. You have the run-and-gunners, the hop-n-bops, the Metroidvanias, the collect-a-thons, those with realistic physics, the platform hells, the list goes on and on...However, there is a rare breed of platformer that comes out every so often that defies many of the traditional sub-genre aspects and manages to be it's own unique experience.Psychonauts is one of those games.The story of the begins with Raz running away from home to become a Psychonaut, a kind of mixture between a secret agent and mental projectionist. He is taken in by the training camp, set into a journey that has him entering mind after bizarre mind to solve a sinister brain stealing plot.With mental focus being the theme of the game, Raz learns many useful abilities such as levitation, telekinesis, and even seeing how others see the world. Upgrades and useful items are everywhere and the unique locals make the exploring the various mindsets to be all the more enjoyable. The humor is also some of the most well-written and goes hand-in-hand with the stylized look. One could easily picture a Nicktoon based on the game.Infamously bombing on it's intially release, it's earned a new life as time went on. For those looking for a unique 3D platformer on the PC, this is the first stop.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												---CONTAINS SPOILERS---4/5 ☆Having spent 30 odd hours on the game and finally unlocking all of the achievements, it's time for my honest opinion and review of Psychonauts.A fascinating game with a somewhat odd, edging on bizarre story - but that's what's so appealing about it. It's a great 3D platformer that can keep you going for hours if you want to do everything 100%, with plenty of collectibles and secrets to uncover. If you like games like Ratchet and Clank, you'll enjoy this one.The environments are vast and have plenty of exploration potential, some a bit more simple like the campgrounds and others considerably more complex like inside the minds of some of the characters you encounter, twisting and turning three-dimensionally around you. It's a great big basket of weird shaped fruit that you just want to dig into, fiddling and raising an eyebrow at each new stage's design and mechanics which in all comes together as a big ball of appealing 'wtf' that the game's story is in general. The music and sounds also help to fit in with this asylum theme of the game, they just seem to click nicely together and set the stage (pun quite literally intended in Gloria's mind) of that particular character's psyche, with the crazy and slightly disturbing nature of the last stage's music topping it all off. The story seemed to escalate quickly, going from training and learning about your psychic powers to suddenly thwarting an evil brain snatching plot to take over the world. I suppose it again adds to the bizzaro charm of the game. You encounter along your way people with multiple personae, anger issues, traumatic events and resentment and the like. I find that sort of stuff very fascinating, even more so how they managed to get it to blend together in a story as it did.It did however have it's fair share of negatives, though most are technical.Crashes for example are a big issue. Within my first couple of hours in the game I had several rather annoying crashes as I tried to make my way up to the Basic Braining segment. The message of 'Psychnoats is not responding and needs to be shut down' popped up a fair few times on my journey through the game. I advise anyone interested in playing this game to SAVE VERY OFTEN - which isn't a bad practice to get into the habit of doing so anyway for any game. There are also instances where the game 'freezes' but doesn't crash. Watch out for these, as you can still play the game, as long as you don't fidget with your keyboard or controller. Basically, the screen will freeze, but the music may still play. Give it a few seconds and it will start moving again. It usually stutters a bit before this happens (at least in my experience), a decent indicator to quickly hit the save button!Controls. You can play this game with a controller OR a keyboard and mouse. From the start, I would have preferred to use the controller, I believe given the type of game it is, it would have not only been easier to use a controller, but perhaps also more comfortable. However, there are teething issues with plugging in a controller. In my experience, it tended to crash MORE often when the controller was being used, and it had this strange issue where, even if you weren't touching the analogue sticks, Raz would start moving in a random direction, which also applied when operating the menus. I had to in the end unplug the USB receiver for the controller, shut down steam, re-launch and then play with the keyboard and mouse. There are fixes I believe out there via forums and guides, I believe there may be one or two on Steam's community forums, and you can work around them. But the player shouldn't really have to go looking elsewhere for third party fixes when it should have been checked and double checked before throwing it out there by the producers of the game. I used the default keybinds throughout the game, and they were ok, but did feel a bit clustered and clumsy at times. Whether that was my own fault or not is up for debate, but in a frantic battle situation, I found myself constantly hitting the wrong key for my psychic power, or something like Telekinesis cutting out halfway and accidentally dropping the thing or enemy you were engaging with. Things like this I believe would be considerably easier if you used a controller. But you can always change the keybinds to whatever you prefer.Now my biggest pain in the backside with this game. The camera. Oh my lord do I want to strangle that camera. It lets you down in places you need it most, such as to try and get an angle right for a jump, such as that 'don't drown' ascending acrobatic bit in the final boss area and that hovering spiralling segmented climable netting/mesh bit. That was the single most frutrating part of the whole finale, if not the whole game. It's smooth sailing with the odd bumps up until there and after it, but by God did that take me a while - because you had to wrestle with the camera WHILE attempting the difficult manoeuvre, a sort of manoeuvre you hadn't faced before in any earlier part of the game, and one that I adamantly believe cannot be done without deliberately taking damage from a burning section of the mesh in order to gain enough height to make the tricky jump. When you want to look around to explore and scout out collectibles, you feel rather restricted. Even with high mouse sensitivity, I found myself having to skid the mouse over and over again to have a good look around and even then it seemed to move just as slow. It just adds unnecessary frustration when you're trying to enjoy and immerse yourself in the game's surroundings and puzzles. Again, I believe this wouldn't be an issue if you were to use a controller to play instead of the keyboard and mouse.To finish off my criticisms (in case I start to inflate and turn purple, becoming a Jasper the Critic 2.0 and spit my popcorn at you), I'll have a quick snip at maps. In short: there aren't any! Ok, well, yes, there is one, for the campgrounds, an area that you won't be visiting as often after you can cross the lake, and an area you can't even return to after you hit the 'Point of No Return'. No other map. At all. For any other area. And yet, there is a MAP TAB on the main menu, which only displays as 'out of map range' when you're in any area other than the campgrounds. That was a bit disappointing in my opinion, a huge potential for additional exploration and aiding in finding collectibles was missed there.Finally, the achievements in this game – be careful everyone! It's one of those games where after you hit a certain 'Point of No Return' – you won't be able to go back to some areas to collect stuff for some achievements, and you may miss some 'witness' achievements altogether unless you know when and where to go look for them in-between the different points of the story. I had to start another game from scratch to get the Pokeylope related achievement for example. I'd suggest making lots of separate saves  to help counter this.To close, it's a weird and wonderful game that I enjoyed very much and would recommend to others. But to those others that are interested, I would strongly suggest you grab a controller and get that working properly – I believe it will make things a heck of a lot less frustrating and smoother to play with. As well as SAVING EVERY OTHER MINUTE to prevent getting setbacks from those nasty random crashes and freezes.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												How can I explain Psychonauts? You take the personality and charm of Earthbound, the gameplay of Conker's Bad Fur Day, and the visuals of A Nightmare Before Christmas; drop all of that into a blender, and you get this amazing game. I don't really know what else to say really aside from "buy it". So, buy it. Buy it seven times if you feel like it. Just play this game.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2011
												Psychonauts seems to be finally getting the respect it deserves. Apparently action-adventure platformers are something of a niche genre nowadays, but at least they are still being made. Not everything has to be a first-person shooter, especially if you're trying to tell as involving a story as this one.I won't say too much as I don't want to spoil it for those who don't know and are tempted, but if you give Psychonauts a chance you'll find it very rewarding. Fascinatingly creative level design, a hilarous script and top-notch voice acting make this game a delight the entire way though.Well, with the possible exception of Meat Circus. You know what I'm talking about.The only possible gripe I'd have about this game is that the controls are a little lacking, but hopefully by the time you need to be fast and accurate you'll have mastered them. Well, that and the fact they have a sequel hook that hasn't been resolved.Come on, people! Psychonauts is now getting the recognition it deserves, but that's not how the industry works! Less than 100,000 copies in it's first year does not feed the developers. If we don't take a chance on quirky, unusual games, all we'll have soon is Assassin's Creed 14 and Call of Duty 37. Tim Schafer deserves better than this.I've also nominated this game for a Steam award. You should too.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												Psychonauts is a fantastic game, I would end the review here and tell you to "just buy it", but since this is by far one of the best games I have played on any platform, I need to say a few things about it.Now this is an action platformer. There's platforming, and alongside that there are enemies and obstacles to overcome. The platforming at a few times felt clunky, but for the most part was an enjoyable experience. But the game's fun isn't in the platforming or whatever, it's everything about this game that makes it the wonderful experience that it is. And that's what it is, an experience. It's strange, quirky, full of personality, and original. No matter if you're just sitting around listening to character's clever dialouge, or exploring the vast enviroments searching for plentiful goodies, you're always going to be entertained.I can't go any further without spoiling any of the plot, but I can whole-heartedly say this game is utterly fantastic, and has aged like fine wine. Yeah it's old now, and it's not the prettiest looking thing, but it's still beautiful and elegant in it's own little way.>Good characters>Great, unique story>Good gameplay>Funny DIalouge>Excellent score and voice acting>Decent controls (as long as you're using a controller that is, idk about the mouse and keyboard but i wouldn't try it)>Fun enviroments that are each uniqueThe only shortomings I've had with the game are some parts of levels that were very frustrating, because sometimes you on't have a good idea on what you should be doing at some point. But when you figure it out, you feel like a ♥♥♥♥ing idiot. Not really the game's fault, more or less my own, but I still would have liked more direction at certain points.Also some enemies that kept respawning were annoying but whatever.Overall, this game is fantastic, and you should totally get it.TL;DR : ♥♥♥♥ing buy it you nerds.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
												It has been a long long time since i have fallen in love with a video game so quickly. I only recently finished my playthrough of Psychonauts, and i loved every little minute of it. Previously, i had heard many say that Psychonauts was an underappreciated hidden gem, that deserved so much more. To be honest i thought these people were simply over exaggerating the greatness of this game. As i soon learned my opinion was that of a fool's. Psychonauts blew me away as I began to play it. From the very beginning i knew that i would love this game, and its estetic. One of the very first things i noticed right away was visually, how everything looked. There is a distinct style that every character, and environment has: Nothing has perfect edges and corners. Everything has a slight bend, or at a peculiar angle, but is not to the point where it is jarring to the eyes, or unpleasant. This gives the game a unique look, that is not easily duplicated. Every environment seems different from the last, with it's own singular theme, that makes it look as though it could stand on its own. I enjoy this, because different places and levels SHOULD be solitary in their style. Different characters personalities reflect their their subconscious, giving you the true impression that you are in THIS person's mind. And each character has their own distinct personality, from the kids in the camp, to the coaches teaching. They all have a trait, or something more to them that grants them lots of... I guess the best way to describe it would be quirkiness. There is just something to them... I just love the way they act, the things they talk about, actions, responses, jokes, etc. Many a time have i been playing this game with a giant♥♥♥♥♥♥eating grin on my face, because of something somone did.  All of the characters in this game, even the protaganists, and enemies, are lovable. However the most lovable of all is your main character Razz (can't remember if im spelling that right). He somehow captures the essence of childlike wonder, and reminds me alot of myself when i was a kid. He somehow just has this... draw to him, somehting about him that makes you proud to play as him as you progress to the story, you see his character grow immensly. Moving right along to the story, I won't say much, you can watch the trailer if you want a preview, but I'll leave it at this. I couldn't  stop playing. I wanted to see what would happen next; who's mind I would enter, I just wanted more and more and more. I was entranced in the deep and moving narrative. Even at the end of the game, i found myself wanting more, and was genuinely sad when i realized I was probably on the final level. This was partly established because of the story, but also because of how engaging and fun the gameplay was. You utilize your own psychic abilities, which you earn via merrit badges. You earn these throughout the story, and by occasionally ranking up (which can be done by various means.) Every ability has their own time and place, and unlike most games (cough cough Tomb Raider reboot) you dont learn a certain ability and then never use it in the game ever again. There's always a time and place for  to a certain ability, and all of them are useful. Now some of these abilities are combat based, others movement or puzzle based. Psychonauts blends solid platforming with puzzle solving (I'm not really talking Legend of Zelda style puzzles, more puzzles you need to use your head to solve. Yes that pun was intended), along with a banjo Kazooie esque exploration. Along with fun combat and a ton of collectables to... collect. There is a lot to do in Psychonauts,  one can spend hours engaged in this masterpiece. However, this game is not that difficult, I didnt have that hard a time playing through it. There are moments where it has its difficulties, sometimes it may be vague (but this isnt too jarring or game breaking. Just a little difficulty finding where or what one must do to progress. I only had this problem once). But on the upside no major glitches, or save problems, etc.  Personally i love this game, and i knew it after about 20 minutes of playing. So i was thouroughly happy when i got more than my money's worth for a far longer game than i had expected. So am I here to tell you that Psychonauts is the most underrated games of the century and that Tim Shcafer is a god, like most of the internet (or people on the internet ive hear say that), no. I'm here to tell you that Psychonauts is a damn good game that I'm glad as hell glad I got it. And I'm not here to tell you its an underappreciated gem, I'm just here to tell you its a gem. I love it, and I'm sure you will too.

												This is one of my all time favorite games and you should play it. I don't know what else to write so here is a recipe for the only thing I know of that is almost as good as this game INGREDIENTS:1 cup powdered sugar1/2 cup creamy peanut butter2 small boxes of instant vanilla pudding (home made pudding is better but instant is far easier) 1 (9-inch) gram cracker pie crust 2 cups whipped creamSlightly adapted from The Amish CookDIRECTIONS:in one bowl make puddingin an other bowl mix peanut butter and powdered sugar until you have a bowl of little peanut butter nuggets.After pudding is somewhat cool you can start to assemble the pie.Add half the peanut butter nuggets to the bottom of the pie shell. Top with pudding. Add half the remaining peanut butter nuggets to the top of the pudding.Top with whipped cream and remaining peanut butter nuggets.Let the pie cool in the refrigerator for at least 2 hours to set up before cutting.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2011
												Psychonauts seems to be finally getting the respect it deserves. Apparently action-adventure platformers are something of a niche genre nowadays, but at least they are still being made. Not everything has to be a first-person shooter, especially if you're trying to tell as involving a story as this one.I won't say too much as I don't want to spoil it for those who don't know and are tempted, but if you give Psychonauts a chance you'll find it very rewarding. Fascinatingly creative level design, a hilarous script and top-notch voice acting make this game a delight the entire way though.Well, with the possible exception of Meat Circus. You know what I'm talking about.The only possible gripe I'd have about this game is that the controls are a little lacking, but hopefully by the time you need to be fast and accurate you'll have mastered them. Well, that and the fact they have a sequel hook that hasn't been resolved.Come on, people! Psychonauts is now getting the recognition it deserves, but that's not how the industry works! Less than 100,000 copies in it's first year does not feed the developers. If we don't take a chance on quirky, unusual games, all we'll have soon is Assassin's Creed 14 and Call of Duty 37. Tim Schafer deserves better than this.I've also nominated this game for a Steam award. You should too.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												Absolutely incredible game. Still able to be played today. After a while, you don't notice the aged graphics, because cartoony graphics age well.Gameplay is great. Story is great. Characters are great.Exploring is a blast as well, because the setting is unique... you play as a psychic child in a camp for other psychics. Reminds me of a few of my school camps.This game comes from a time when games didn't have to be excessively violent to allow for great gameplay, and when singleplayer campaigns actually had some love and dedication put into them. There needs to be more games like this.Well, what are you waiting for? Chuck your goggles on and embark on your journey to become a Psychonaut!

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												This game is really hard to explain but it has so much charm and is one of the best adventure games i have ever played. Every time I've beaten it (4 times not just Steam edition), I have always encountered new little easter eggs that are super easy to miss, it might seem linear but if you explore you will be surprised how much humor this game has, you can tell they definitely put so much time and effort into this game. It's a very rare game indeed, even the music and characters warm you up lol honestly I duno what it is about this game but it just brings back amazing fun memories, from when I remember playing it back in the day. Can't wait for the sequel!Pros:- Actually hilarious humor- Each level is unique in every way- Very colorful game actually has aged quit well- Memorable characters- Really good voice actors and music/sound- Has replayability if you into getting achievements and easter eggsThere is a reason the overall reviews are "Overwhelmingly Positive"!Cons:- Kinda short- Once you beat it 101% nothing else to do- Camera and controls are ok, but you can get used to itHonestly though for the price it is now you can't really complain.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												If anyone is reading this review and is thinking "is this game as good as people say?" my response is: yes, it is as good as people tell you.lets get into the pro's of the game:+ the clever, hilarious writing shines if you focus/listen to the diolog.+ the game holds up well for a game as old as it is: i.e the graphics, cutscenes (kind of), gameplay, etc. (if you have the right graphics card (I'll get into that))+ the levitation ability: it gives you access to everything you can see (whether it be through an exploit (possibly removed) or due to how fast, floaty and fun it is)+ the collectables (i.e the memory vaults and emotional baggage) are quite rewarding and makes you feel smart.+ it's challanging enough to make it satisfiying, but not hard enough to hate it (but you may experience some anger on the parts where it's obvious (*cough* *cough* black velvitopia *cough* *cough* meat cirus *cough* *cough*))+ there are probably pro's, but I can't think of any right now.As for the cons, there is no shortage of them, so, just be aware of the following:- if you are trying to go for 100% compleition , I wish you luck you sorry sod, because the other collectible I didn't mention were figments, one of the 4 ways of leveling up. they are so indestinct that it makes completing this game 100% a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥and practiacally soul consuming (this problem is amplified in the levitation stage and waterloo world)- you can tell that this is doublefines' first 3d platformer, and, while I say it's an amazing first attempt, it kinda shows when you're stuck in a rock (like Delfy) or when the game turns a 180 on your♥♥♥♥♥and works against you (i.e the physics, camara, controls, etc).- if you plan on using your keyboard and make custom bindings, um, well... I would advise using a controller: the layout is simple and easy to use. As for custom bindings, if you quit the game, you may as well say goodbye to the time you spent. bindings are pointless as they go away after guiting the game to go grab a pizza or something, hence, why I'd advise using a controller- I'd also advice getting a really good, non amd graphics card, otherwise everything just looks glitchy.- meat cirus... 'nuff said.it may seem I have a lot of negative to say about this game and I don't like it, but, I really do enjoy and I'd recomend it to a friend.however, I'd only reccommend it to someone who is good at video games, like, really good at video games.Also, the positives will heavily outweigh the negatives. Like I said with the diolog, but, really, whatever positives there are really shines through. By all means this game is not perfect, but, you should at least give it a try. I'd rate this game 8/10 would advise using a controller

content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												Gex + Banjo Kazooie + Camp Lazlo + psychic powers. Do yourself a favor if you ever get around to playing this gem.Do not go out of the way to collect the little bananas/musical notes/figments. Getting every little item might satisfy your OCD but will detract from the experience overall when you spend upwards of an hour or more on each and every map combing every square inch for that little picture that fades in and out. When you get to the end of the game it automatically creates a point-of-no return save. You can use that save and from there revisit ever level to get every little item but only IF you feel so inclined. Once you hit the point of no return just fling yourself at that brick wall of a final level and it will crumble against your fists oh so satisfyingly. Intentinoally annoying characters have never been good. They will continue to never be good. Physics can be a real♥♥♥♥♥pain (lol 3D platformers) but this game is practically devoid of any punishment for messing up. The less you participate in scavenging the more fun you will have.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												Psychonauts is a classic action/adventure platformer which follows the story of a young psychic named Raz. In his quest to join the Psychonauts - an elite group of international psychic secret agents--he breaks into their secret training facility: Whispering Rock Psychic Summer Camp. But this is no average psychic summer camp! A mysterious villain has kidnapped Raz’s fellow campers and stolen their brains. Now he must use his psychic powers of Telekinesis, Levitation, and most of all his ability to project himself into the minds of others--to find the loose noodles and keep them from falling into the wrong hands. Fight mental demons! Uncover hidden memories! Sort emotional baggage!Psychonauts has a quite unique story and level design in addition to various kinds of psychic abilities. Raz's character is pretty well developed. He is perhaps the best voiced character in game. However the other characters are pretty dull and not quite well developed. They are pretty forgettable. In terms of visuals Psychonauts is pretty decent with some pretty good art work complimented with some wonderful sound production which plays a huge part in the game. The level design is great and solving puzzles can be fun as every puzzle has something unique to offer Pros:- Stunning Visuals - Wonderful sound production- Voice Acting- Save Anywhere- Decent PuzzlesCons:- Troublesome Camera Controls- Few blocky objects- Forgettable Characters

content:
Posted: October 3, 2015
												Psychonauts : โครตพลังจิตป่วนหัวคนบ้า(7/10 B++)ก่อนจะมี brutal legends เรามี Psychonauts เป็นความสำเร็จหลักของ Double Fine  ผมจำได้ว่า ได้เห็นเกมนี้ครั้งแรกทางช่อง G4 ที่ true เอามาฉายตอนนั้น มันมาเป็นรายการสารคดีของตัวเกม Psychonauts ที่ฉายให้เห็นถึงช่วงเวลา 1 อาทิตย์สุดท้ายก่อนเกมจะวางขาย ผมได้ฟังสิ่งที่ผู้พัฒนาเกม บอกถึงความน่าสนใขของตัวเกม แล้วผมชอบแนวคิดของเกมมาก ที่ว่าด้วยเรื่องการเข้าไปในจิตใจของคนอื่น บวกกับค่ายที่ฝึกสอนสายลับผู้มีพลังจิต(เหมือนลอก XMEN มาเลย)ตัวเกมจะเป็นแนวกึ่งเดินตะลุยกึ่ง open world เกมค่อนข้างที่จะมีอิสระให้เราไปไหนมาไหน แต่ก็จะบังคับให้เราทำภารกิจหลักตลอด(สมัยนั้น เกม open world ยังไม่บูมมาก) โดยเฉพาะการเข้าไปในหัวของคนอื่น ซึ่งผมว่ามันเจ๋งมาก เหมือนเราได้เห็นโลกที่อยู่ในหัวของคนๆหนึ่ง (เหมือนหนังเรื่อง being john malkovich ) ตัวเกมจะสลับกับระหว่างโลกจริงกับโลกในจิตใจไปๆมาๆ โดยจุดหมายของเกมคือการแก้ปัญหาทางสภาพจิตใจในหัวของคนอื่นไปเรื่อยๆการออกแบบตัวละครกับโลกในเกมดูคล้ายๆหลุดออกมาจากหนังของ tim burtonระบบการเล่น : ตัวเกมจะเป็นแนวเดินตะลุยแก้ปริศษาไปตามทาง เดินๆย้อนไปย้อนมาบ้าง หลังๆมันจะคล้ายๆกับ mario 64 มากระบบการต่อสู้ผมว่ามันทำออกมาไม่ค่อยมีดี เพราะส่วนใหญ่เกมมันจะเน้นให้คุยเยอะ การต่อสู้ระหว่างทางมันเลยทำให้ดูน่าเบื่อตลอดทั้งเกม แต่กลับกันผมกลับชอบการสู้บอส ของเกมนี้มาก ทั้งสนุกบวกฮา การสู้กับบอสดูจะให้เราใช้สมองอยู่พอตัว ก็ตามแบบฉบับเกมสมัยก่อนที่วิธีการกำจัดบอสนั้นมีวิธีของมัน ไม่ใช้ฟัดๆหลับๆอย่างเดียวภาพ : จัดอยู่ในระดับกลาง เป็นภาพการ์ตูนที่ดูไม่สวยอะไรมาก แต่บอกตามตรงเห็นครั้งผมนึกถึงหนังของ tim burton โครต ทั้งการออกแบบตัวละคร การออกแบบโลกในหัวคนอื่นหรือแม้กระทั้งเพลงประกอบข้อเสีย : -เกมมี bugs ให้เห็รอยู่บางส่วน โดยเฉพาะ พวก bugs ติดกำแพง ติดบันไดบางสรุป : ผมว่าเกมนี้ทำออกมาค่อนข้างดีเลยนะ ถึงมันจะเป็นแค่เกมเด็กเล่น ที่เล่นข้ามเวลาแล้วตัวเกมก็ไม่ได้ยาวอะไร ผมเล่นแล้วก็เพลินๆดี ผ่านไปได้ แต่มันก็มีบางจุดเหมือนกันที่มันน่าเบื่อ เช่น ฉากที่เราจะต้อง เดินเข้าตัวตึก แล้วมีใยแมงมุมขวางประตู เราต้องใช้เงินจำนวนหนึ่้งไปซื้อเครื่องกำจัดใย แล้วเกมก็จะบังคับเราให้ไปซื้อไอ้เครื่องนั้นอย่างเดียว ซึ่งผมว่ามันน่าเบื่อโครต เพราะเราต้องมานั่งเสียเวลาเก็บใบไม้ม่วงเฮงซวยที่ใช้แทนค่าเงิน เพื่อไปซื้อเครื่องกำจัดใย แล้วใช้มันผ่านประตูแค่ครั้งเดียวของเกม

content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
												For all its imaginative flair, people are going to be put off by Psychonauts’ haphazard assembly; it has all the mechanical aspects of a product not quite completed, made by people not entirely sure what they were doing. At some point, the game decides you’ve spent enough time learning how it’s supposed to work and assumes you can effortlessly pull off a series of challenging jumps, or that you’ve mastered its fumbling combat system. You haven’t; of course you haven’t, and what follows is a chorus of curses and rage-quitting or, in the case of the poor saps trying to play this on a keyboard, uncontrollable rage. But for those who can work past these flaws, Psychonauts has traits that seem largely forgotten in today’s conveyer belt of annual sequels and follow-the-fad gameplay. It’s genuinely funny, for one and has just the right amount of surrealist endearment and adolescent awkwardness to make it completely unique. There’s nothing else out there quite like Psychonauts, where you can be fighting a lucha libre wrestling cat pretending to be an eagle in a neon pastel ring one moment, then be terrorising a city full of tiny lumpy fishmen as a Godzilla-sized monster the very next. Where you can be listening to a classmate tell you that his tin foil hat stops him accidently exploding faces or another one trying to sneak time on the camp radio to return to her home planet, because she feels this world is doomed. Full Review // http://www.honestgamers.com/12430/pc/psychonauts/review.html

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
												This is one of the best games I've ever played- hands down, this game is a masterpiece. The story of this game is amazing, well thought through, and overwhelmingly humorous, and very challenging. It actually feels like the creators took more than 2 months like normal games do to make the plot. Overall I really cannot explain the plot in depth to give a great feeling, so just go enjoy it yourself. Psychonauts is also a giant game- leaving 48.2 hours of mine JUST for the story, and not for going back for the thousands of collectables this game has to offer.What some people assume and will assume is the strange art of the game. The art looks a litte odd, but overall it gets normal, and cartoonish and funny as well. Sure, its not your average realistic art, but as you venture deeper into the art, it really shapes the game as to what the gameplay is; which is traveling inside the minds of others and fixing their mental state, which appears to be either a compact, organized mind, as simple as a theatre, or even a twisty and odd, but amazingly humorous neighborhood.Overall, this game I think deserves a 10/10 for me. This is one of the best games over the thousands I've ever played, including cross platform. Yes, I'm talking about one of the top games I've played compared to PlayStation consoles, Xbox consoles, handhelds, Nintendo consoles, iOS and Android, and desktop/PC/computer. I've never in my life played a story in a game as good as this. My only regret of this game is beating it, as I don't know what to do now.......And also for Notch to not fund a sequel to the game. Why Notch, WHY!!! It's only 18 million, thats 1/300 out of your pocket.

Posted: March 3, 2014
												I missed Psychonaut when it first came out in 2006 and only heard about it a few years later. I only just recently finally decided to play it and I'm so glad I did. Psychonaut is an adventure platforming game with a great story and humor. Psychonaut are special people gifted with psychics abilities. You play the game as Raz, the new kid of a psychonaut summercamp. What makes this game intersting is the variety of game mechanics that it introduces. As a psychonaut, you can enter into other people's mind. All the characters are very well designed and their levels are completly different. Even today, this game still looks really innovative. Finally, the game really aged well. The graphics and gameplay are still very good. If you want to play one of the best games from the PS2/Xbox era, this is it.

												Without a doubt, the guys at Double Fine know how to make a fun and challenging game. Psychonauts is fun and it does get challenging towards the end as well as it gets just a bit frustrating, contrasting with the rest of the game. There's also a lot of stuff to do, lots of collectibles and secrets to find, achievements are a blast to pursuit. What they always seem to make perfect, however, are the characters. I mostly recommend trying to get the "I LOVE PUNCHING!" achievement, as it's one of the most anoying yet satisfying once completed achievements in a video game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 20, 2015
												More detail can be found further in.Good -- -Excellent voice acting and dialogue. -Fun story -Very well designed, fully fleshed-out charactersBad -- - Audio and port issues - Minor design flawsDebatable -- - Balancing issues - game visuals look good, despite age - some poor design choices - music was goodAs a general overview, Psychonauts is a rather old game that has a lot of hype behind it. This is the first time I've played it, and was informed of the game by every gaming youtuber ever saying it's amazing. I found the game to be fun, but frustrating at times. The gameplay is basically that of a Third-Person Collect-Um-Up (Similar to Spyro, for example). The voice acting, dialogue, story, and visuals were big pluses for me. Add to that some very strong, well realized character, and you have something special. The quality of the features listed above were a surprise. The strong parts of the game vastly outweigh the negatives.So to get into it - Voice acting and dialogue - The quality of the writing in this game was a delight. No lines stood out to me as awkward or poorly delivered. It felt like Triple A quality.- Story - The story is fairly simple. The main character, Raz, runs away from home to go to a summer camp. This summer camp caters to psychics, and Raz, with innate psychic powers, fits right it as he waits for his father to pick him up. Along the way, Raz stumbles on a conspiracy that forces him to use his powers to save the day. It's not too heavy, but gets a lot darker in places. Most of the dark parts are optional, and were an appreciated surprise to find. The story doesn't feel stale or overused. In fact, it feels fresh to this day. - The characters - The characters of this game are wonderful. Every single one is well designed, well voice-acted. nnd has interesting dialogue. Their personalities are conveyed well, and each has something interesting to say. They feel like characters, as opposed to throwaway NPC's that are common in other games.- Visuals - The visuals have aged well, in my opinion. The cartoonish, and totally non-realistic look helps immensely with that. It's colorful, and looks great in motion. - Gameplay - The gameplay is simple and fun, but has its hiccups at times. The powers you gain are all useful, fun, and/or overpowered in some way. Some abilities are only useful as a way to flesh out the world and your understanding of some characters. Others will be used almost constantly as they have too many uses that help you progress. The platforming in this game is made easier by certain powers, but here is were some problems come in. The geometry of the world can screw you sometimes. For example, on grind rails, you can get stuck and be unable to    go forward. Conversely, you can be going so fast that you literally fly off (or the game forces you to follow the rail path, making it appear as is Raz is flying). Some ledges don't want to let you grab them, and others will cancel you active    powers. This is annoying and can result in you falling and have to being the climb all over again. The game has these little frustrations spattered throughout.-Balancing issues - This game has one of 2 problems, either it's too easy or it's too hard. There is no in-between, and that is frustrating. Whether the game is one of the other depends on how thorough you are with the collecting. If you try to collect everything, you will feel overpowered as i did. If you just run to objectives and only get levels when necessary, the game will be much harder. This can be a tad annoying, or insanely frustrating depending on which problem you have. It isn't game breaking, but it can take away from an otherwise fantastic experience.- Poor design choices - There were moments in the game that felt like poor choices on the developers end. Basically, some of the visual design makes things confusing. There were points where i got stuck, because i didn't know what was a platform and what wasn't, or what walls were scalable and what weren't. There were times when i died or lost a lot of progress because a thick ledge turned out to be an invisible wall. Again, it isn't game breaking. Instead, it's another frustration that i had throw on the pile. - Audio issues - The game had some audio issues were some things were too loud or quite. An example would be the fire lighting the main lodge at night. It sounded ike the entire building is on fire. Also, there were time where the dialogue volume would drop or spike for no reason.- Bugs and other issues - So this is a major failing on the game, and one of the only game breaking things i have to say about the game. Before I elaborate, i will say that there are fixes for the issues to be listed.    -- Crashing -- The game will crash, and it will do so a lot. This will often happen between areas. I found that it didn't crash until later, but it would crash often after it started. The crashes vary from just closing the game, failing to respond, or forcing you to restart you PC. The game auto saves (thank god), but it will keep happening unless you fix it. The fix is so stupidly easy, that i'm am shocked the crashing occurs at all. You need to change the compatability from Windows xp (or whatever it is) to Windows 97.    -- Audio bugs -- There will be occasional popping sounds and jagged noises for some (but not all). There is a fix, but i don't know it.   -- Controller prompts -- the game defaults to keyboard, and all commands will appear as keyboard keys. Even if you are using a controller, prompts will be for the keyboard. All keys and buttons are rebindable, but you need to use a fairly complex fix to get controller prompts to workOverall -- The game is a lot of fun. The fun is often punctuated by moments of frustration. It ends up being a fairly solid game that lacks a bit of polish in the gameplay and visual design. Definitely worth playing, but you will have to work for your fun at times.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2012
												A long time ago, I read a magazine article (back when they existed) that listed Psychonauts as the best game you never played that given year. While I do not normally take too much direction from magazines or web sites I thought I would take this one recommendation and some time later (it takes time for me to get around to things) I sauntered over to the game store and found a XBox copy in their used section and picked it up. I can say now that the magazine was definately accurate in its description as a good game but was no longer accurate in saying that I had not played it.I'm old enough to have grown up playing that classic platformers of the NES and SNES era and was always a fan of such games. When Mario 64 came out I was immediately impressed the platformers transition to 3D gaming. Psychonauts is compariable to Mario 64 in much of the basics of 3D platforming but with some evolution beyond Mario 64. First, there is an actual story to follow; second there are slightly more fleshed out characters; and third the environments have moved beyond the obvious themes (fire, ice, castle) of Mario style platformers.The story is fun and highly comedic. It at times will play with a trope and try to switch it up; such as the child running away from the circus. The characters themselves have some interesting details and various quirks and with some of the characters you get to dive right into their mind to explore them in a little more detail even if surreal and filled with metaphors. It is these trips into a characters mind that allows the game environment to shine and be unique and evolutionary. Unfortunately, the number of minds you get to explore felt too few mainly because they were so enterataining and I so wanted more. Thankfully, there is now a Psychonauts 2 coming down the pipe.Somewhere in this simple review I wanted to make a play on the term minefield/mindfield but just couldn't get it to work so there we have it. Psychonauts is one of my favorite games and one of the few I have actually gotten around to finishing and completing (twice even, thanks to getting it again on Steam).(This review done under duress in order to complete the 2016 Autumn Sale badge.)

Posted: December 13, 2014
												For all its imaginative flair, people are going to be put off by Psychonauts’ haphazard assembly; it has all the mechanical aspects of a product not quite completed, made by people not entirely sure what they were doing. At some point, the game decides you’ve spent enough time learning how it’s supposed to work and assumes you can effortlessly pull off a series of challenging jumps, or that you’ve mastered its fumbling combat system. You haven’t; of course you haven’t, and what follows is a chorus of curses and rage-quitting or, in the case of the poor saps trying to play this on a keyboard, uncontrollable rage. But for those who can work past these flaws, Psychonauts has traits that seem largely forgotten in today’s conveyer belt of annual sequels and follow-the-fad gameplay. It’s genuinely funny, for one and has just the right amount of surrealist endearment and adolescent awkwardness to make it completely unique. There’s nothing else out there quite like Psychonauts, where you can be fighting a lucha libre wrestling cat pretending to be an eagle in a neon pastel ring one moment, then be terrorising a city full of tiny lumpy fishmen as a Godzilla-sized monster the very next. Where you can be listening to a classmate tell you that his tin foil hat stops him accidently exploding faces or another one trying to sneak time on the camp radio to return to her home planet, because she feels this world is doomed. Full Review // http://www.honestgamers.com/12430/pc/psychonauts/review.html

content:
Posted: December 14, 2012
												I just finished my first playthrough of this game 7 and a half years after its release.  It's a very strange game to be sure.  It is a very unique concept playing a child who is training to be a psychic warrior, battling monsters inside other people's minds.  The game is very well written and despite being so stylized, the characters are quite realistic (though a few of them are fairly annoying.)  It also still manages to be quite humorous despite its age.The game's setting at a kids' summer camp and the art style lead me to believe the game is aimed at kids, yet the subject matter is a bit more mature.  I think the game would be much too difficult for children as well.  It's a bit confusing for me.Now Double Fine was nice enough to update the game for Steam after many years which I greatly appreciate.  After putting in that effort though, I'd think they would have fixed some of the outstanding bugs.  I ran into quite a few ladders with broken dismounts at the top (one was so bad it took me about 10 tries each time to get off the ladder at the top and I had to climb it 10+ times) and a few other level glitches.  There are quite a few really badly placed fixed camera angles throughout the game.  The "smart camera" won't turn off despite changing the setting so the keyboard/mouse controls as essentially unusable.  I highly recommend downloading a mod called PsychoPad which gives you a modern gamepad layout with proper button prompts for the standard 360 controller (something else I think Double Fine should've taken care of.)Overall a very enjoyable game, though I wouldn't go so far as to call it a classic like many people do.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
												This is one of the best games I've ever played- hands down, this game is a masterpiece. The story of this game is amazing, well thought through, and overwhelmingly humorous, and very challenging. It actually feels like the creators took more than 2 months like normal games do to make the plot. Overall I really cannot explain the plot in depth to give a great feeling, so just go enjoy it yourself. Psychonauts is also a giant game- leaving 48.2 hours of mine JUST for the story, and not for going back for the thousands of collectables this game has to offer.What some people assume and will assume is the strange art of the game. The art looks a litte odd, but overall it gets normal, and cartoonish and funny as well. Sure, its not your average realistic art, but as you venture deeper into the art, it really shapes the game as to what the gameplay is; which is traveling inside the minds of others and fixing their mental state, which appears to be either a compact, organized mind, as simple as a theatre, or even a twisty and odd, but amazingly humorous neighborhood.Overall, this game I think deserves a 10/10 for me. This is one of the best games over the thousands I've ever played, including cross platform. Yes, I'm talking about one of the top games I've played compared to PlayStation consoles, Xbox consoles, handhelds, Nintendo consoles, iOS and Android, and desktop/PC/computer. I've never in my life played a story in a game as good as this. My only regret of this game is beating it, as I don't know what to do now.......And also for Notch to not fund a sequel to the game. Why Notch, WHY!!! It's only 18 million, thats 1/300 out of your pocket.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2013
												Hands down my favorite Double Fine game, and definitely high in my top 10 all-time favorite games (if not tied for #1). Psychonauts has some of the most interesting level designs and quirky humor/style you'll find in any game, with the Invader Zim voice actor as your main character being icing on the cake.The game is a mix of platforming, action, puzzle-solving, and exploration, and it nails all of them. Every level is incredibly unique, often with totally different gameplay mechanics than the next. It is the product of incredibly creative people getting to just go nuts, each putting their own blend of awesome into what they've worked on.Psychonauts is absolutely a must-play for any gamer (assuming you don't *just* play mindless shooters or mobile games), and will make you an instant Double Fine fan. I cannot recommend it enough! Here's to hoping for a sequel in the future as well!

content:
Posted: April 22
												I've never been more unsatisfied or angry at a game in my life, and I don't think I'm hyperbolizing much, despite how that may sound.The real problem is mouse+keyboard is super broken atm and while 80% of the game has been great and I thoroughly enjoyed it, I'm just filled with rage about some of the bosses which I can barely deal with due to "smart camera" being stuck on.  This makes the game force your camera rotation to face the way it thinks you should be looking despite all your best efforts.  You really need to be able to adjust your view angle precisely with the mouse to make acurate jumps and acrobatic movements with the keyboard.  With smart camera stuck on, you simply cannot do that.  This makes the final boss worse than playing I Wanna Be The Guy, which is known for its absurd difficulty, but at least has excellent snappy controls.It sounds like this didn't used to be a problem, but some patch in recent years broke the ability to disable this "smart camera" feature and so we're stuck with it.  INI file editing doesn't help, so I'm considering breaking out a hex editor and mucking with some deeper components of the game.  I may even get a game pad just to finish this game, which I'm loathe to do.I'm not saying you shouldn't play this game, but be ready for this nonsense and maybe just use a controller from the start.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												Really enjoyed this game. It's a platformer in the same mold as games like Spyro or Ratchet and Clank and manages to be a lot of fun. The level design is amazing with some really entertaining and original levels, for example theres one level where you find yourself as a giant in a city  populated by fishmen and you have to rampage through it like Godzilla. There's a lot to do in this game as well with lots of collectibles and different powers to unlock so theres plenty reason to explore the different levels and areas and there's a good 15-20 hours of gameplay if your looking to do everything.The only downsides are that the graphics look quite dated and the camera angles canbe a bit awkward at times but not enough to impact on enjoyment of the game. Also while the game is probably better played with a controller the Xbox controller symbols haven't been added so it's a case of figuring out for yourself which buttons do what.Again this isn't a major issue.Overall this is a really fun game thats really worth playing. It's a 8/10 for me.

Also for everyone having trouble starting the game there is an easy fix . Find your game install folder , right click on psychonauts.exe and select windows95 compitability mode .Also if your audio is stuttering open AudioSettings.ini and change your settings to look like this .[AudioSettings]MasterVolume=1.000000FXVolume=1.000000MusicVolume=1.000000VoiceVolume=1.000000ShowSubtitles=trueHardwareAccel=falseUseEAX=falsePacketSize=850MusicPacketSize=975PreloadVoice=true You can thank me later .

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												Mix "Ratchet & Clank" with "American Mcgee's Alice", and you get Psychonauts!In other words, it's a 3D-collectathon-platformer, filled with whacky action, set into the crazy inner worlds of people's minds.Underneat the somewhat cute-sy (yet clearly a bit bonkers) art style lies some fascinating, yet easy to digest psychological adventure, which even includes some fairly dark elements. Luckily, the game does not rub its grimdark stuff into your face, but it all definitely makes the game a bit more mature experience. There's plenty of great humor involved in everything, and the characters are definitely memorable personalities of their own.The gameplay's not groundbreaking, but the context and story do give a lovely twist to everything. You collect various items and gear, that help you survive within the (more or less unstable) mind-worlds, where you often try to fix and ease people's mental issues. Raz, the MC, is fairly mobile and dexterous, so you get to do lots of jumping, climbing, grinding on thin tracks, and many other fancy acrobatics.I don't know how I managed to skip this little gem back in the days. I started playing Psychonauts for the first time a mere week ago, and now 18 hours later, after the credits have rolled, I simply hunger for more. Luckily, the Psychonauts 2 was just revealed the be in works, so my wait will probably be only a fraction of the old fans'!
