number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												The characters all have really cool designs, although some prominent NPCs have poor textures and model detail, and I wish the player character looked a little less like someone from the movie Antz. The voices all fit their characters perfectly. I love how funny this game is. It managed to make me laugh out loud somehow just about every time I sat down to play it. The storytelling is rather good as well, for the most part. It does seem bound to cliches at times, and it only missteps further when breaking them. For example, it hypes up a bunch of characters with real potential (the "best buddy", the "bully") in a very familiar way, but then just kind of drops them halfway through the game when a more important conflict gets going.I don't play a whole lot of 3D platformers, so maybe I'm out of line here, but the platforming and movement in general feels wonky and primitive. Pole climbing is a travesty: the PC won't always grab on, and touch the invisible border at the top and you'll fall right back to the bottom, and sometimes off a cliff. (A game released today with a problem like this would be excoriated as incomplete and unplayable.) Swinging between horizontal fixtures PoP-style also makes frequent appearances, but there's no puzzle aspect to finding a jumpable route, so it's just busy-work, not difficult but it slows you down anyway. Boss fights are uniformly clunky, unimaginative variations on David and Goliath: dodge the very large enemy's attack to expose a vulnerability, pound away at it, repeat three or four times. An exception to this is the final boss, which is even less complex: avoid the boss until a timer fills up and you go Super Saiyan, at which point the boss puts up a guard that you can break just with a standard attack. It's barely a step up from that old Flash game "You Have To Burn The Rope". If you run out of lives all that happens is you get kicked out of the level and have to waste a few seconds getting back in again, at which point you're dropped at your last checkpoint anyway. As usual, there is virtually no reason to even implement the "lives" mechanic this way in a game you're not putting quarters into.So the game can be an incredible pain. But it's funny, the story is good, the visual design is colorful and refreshing, the gameplay can be innovative and even mind-blowing. With some tweaks it would be a masterpiece.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2011
												This game is not quite what one would expect. On the outside, it looks really cartoony and childish. After a couple of hours of game-time, however, the humor becomes somewhat darker, though still family-friendly. The player assumes the role of Raz, a child gifted with phsycic powers. Raz infiltrates a Psychonauts camp, a summer program for aspiring psychic soldiers. Events soon turn grim as camp staff and attendees begin acting strangely or disappearing entirely. Raz is able to earn and utilize various psychic powers to help him. Levels are designed so that Raz must utilize these powers to be able to progress. Controls take some getting used to, but are OK. They are, however, a major factor in the late game difficulty spike this game is notorious for (this has been patched to with checkpoints).This game is a good choice for a platformer fan.Personally, I was not much of a fan of the environment and personality of the game, but there is nothing actually wrong with the game, other than that the controls are a little loose. This is expected due to porting. It's also funny at times and fairly original.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Hands down the best game I have played in years and most definitely one of my favorite games ever. The story is simply amazing and I love it so much. The visuals are cartoony that simply do not age. It looked great back in the day, it looks great now, and I believe it will continue to look great in the future. It's amazing! The models do show their age with the polygon counts but it just works great alongside the painted textures and actually adds to the atmosphere of the game.The gameplay was unlike anything I've ever played before. It plays like a third person shooter with the psychic powers but somehow it feels so different. I can't quite put my finger on it. There is also a lot of fun platforming and some puzzle solving as well as thousands of little things to collect for points and concept art!The atmosphere of this game is simply the best I've ever experienced. The look and feel of the game really suck you into the story and world. I absolutely love it. I don't recall the music being very prominent in-game but I absolutely love listening to the soundtrack on it's own.The game may be old but it holds up very well. It took me 13 hours to beat and I didn't obsess over every little thing to gather. And there is a lot of stuff to find.----[Rating weighted based on the genre]----Story: 5/5Gameplay: 5/5Challenge: 4/5Discovery: 3/5Replayability: 4/5Aesthetics: 5/5Visuals: 5/5Atmosphere: 10/5Music: 10/5

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2011
												Amazingly well written, a game that actually feels like an adventure. As a Pyschonaut you have to travel into the minds of some fantastically well crafted characters, so there was no limit to how they designed the levels, but rather than use it as an excuse to throw things together loosely and explain it all away, you get inside some very interesting heads and they have a very common and recognisable theme. One of the many highlights is getting inside the head of a Milkman that happens to be a full blown conspiracy nut., or the Godzilla vs Japan style level. It's a great third person action/adventure with loads of cool powers and I must stress, some of the best writing I have ever come across. I'll leave you with this unique quote and if it doesn't sell you, nothing will.G-Man: Although I often smell of excrement, I should not be discriminated against as I provide a valuable service.To say this is merely a game is a gross understatement. This is art.

There are so many little things about this game to love and each time I play I discover something I've never seen before. The gameplay is a little loose but otherwise controls fantastically once you learn to trust the game and its design. My only issue was semi-frequent crashes, but these only occured during screen transitions and more often than not the game autosaved my progress before crashing and at worst I lost only a minute of gameplay with most of that walking. It is a small price to pay for what is in my opinion an otherwise perfect game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												Play. This. Game.This is one of my all time favorite games and I have bought it for multiple platforms for a damn good reason.You are Raz, a circus runaway determined to join the elite ranks of the Psychonauts. He infiltrates a covert training camp for young psychics and must hurry to earn his merit badges before his parents arrive to pick him up.The characters in this are all incredibly well written and rounded, and there's no feeling of forced exposition as you're quite literally infiltrating the minds of your counsellors and "obstacles" (the only way to really describe some of the Asylum patients) so learning their backstory is more along the lines of having read someone's diary and then having them go "oh, uhhh, yeah, I guess you know THAT about me now."The characters are great, the dialogue is great, the voice acting is great, the game play is really good despite the difficulty curve ramping up in a hell of a hurry toward the end.The graphics are dated for sure, but that's easily overlooked as part of the art style.This game may not be for everyone, but if you don't love it I hate you and we can't be friends.9/10

content:
Posted: July 4, 2011
												Amazingly well written, a game that actually feels like an adventure. As a Pyschonaut you have to travel into the minds of some fantastically well crafted characters, so there was no limit to how they designed the levels, but rather than use it as an excuse to throw things together loosely and explain it all away, you get inside some very interesting heads and they have a very common and recognisable theme. One of the many highlights is getting inside the head of a Milkman that happens to be a full blown conspiracy nut., or the Godzilla vs Japan style level. It's a great third person action/adventure with loads of cool powers and I must stress, some of the best writing I have ever come across. I'll leave you with this unique quote and if it doesn't sell you, nothing will.G-Man: Although I often smell of excrement, I should not be discriminated against as I provide a valuable service.To say this is merely a game is a gross understatement. This is art.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												When I was getting this game in a pack with another nice one, I wasn't even sure if it was that good. The trailer and screenshots didn't work that well on me and I mostly wanted it for the other game in the pack. And yet... I played this and... Whoa... This game is a masterpiece! It's a very entertaining game, without voilence, so good for all ages and those who simply don't enjoy killing. Also for those who normally do like bloodshed, I still think you'd find a refreshing change playing this. What genre is it? Hard to say. Kinda platformish, kinda RPG-ish. You control a boy learning to become a psychonaut, travelling in people's minds, where you jump around avoiding the dangers, collecting figments and sorting emotional baggage. You level up as you progress, which is why I say it's RPG-ish a bit too. It also contains a great story with lots of cutscenes, some minigames and it's extremely colourful and pleasant. I love it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
												     The first time I played this game, I shut it off immediately in fear. The opening looked absolutely atrocious. The character design's seemed to come straight from Tim Burton's vision of Hell. The crying and screaming in the background made my head spin. However, I decided to give the game a second go despite my first encounter. Turns out what lay beneath the poorly-aged cutscene was one of my favorite games. I'm enthralled to tell anyone who has even a shred of curiosity to play this game. Immediately. ＳＴＯＲＹ     So, the story here is that a young boy, namely Razputin, has snuck into a summer camp. However, this is no ordinary summer camp, as the camp is entirely based around teaching it's campers psycho-powers (if you couldn't tell from the title). What follows is a bunch of antics with the camp counselors and the other freakish campers. Without giving too much away, (trust me, there's a plethora of story details to give away) the story here is fantastic. Its pacing is seemingly flawless. There are so many interesting reveals and story bits here that most of the time, I was so close to the edge of my seat that if I were as much as poked, I would've fallen off. Trust me, it's finger-licking... good...? (Don't qeustion it. Or do.)ＡＥＳＴＨＥＴＩＣＳ    As stated in the opening, the visual style didn't really appeal to me... at first. The pre-rendered cutscenes are actually quite bad in comparison to the actual engine itself. Never see that nowadays, do ya? I digress, the visual style grew on me after a few minutes of gameplay. The whole thing gives me a Tim Burton-Laika Entertainment (The creators of Coraline) kinda vibe. It's absurdity draws you in and holds you in the world of Psychonauts. This absurdity is incredibly exemplified through each level's design and art direction. It gives each level it's own unique flavor (on top of each level's own uniqueness, but I'll get to that). Besides the pre-rendered cutscenes, the aesthetics have aged like a fine wine, getting seemingly better as the years go on. Sure, you can tell that the game was made in the early 2000's, but that doesn't stop you from watching an old movie, does it? I hope not. I wouldn't be your friend if that werer the case. I can't believe I've gone this long without mentioning the game's score/soundtrack! In short, it's amazing. It fits the mood like a glove filled with Vaseline. I might have to purchase both the score and soundtrack if I can. Anyways, I'd give the aesthetics two thumbs-ups.ＧＡＭＥＰＬＡＹ     Alright, so I'll admit- the gameplay isn't the game's strongest aspect. It has many of the problems 3D platformers of the time faced- bad camera angles, difficulty spikes, unfair platforms, etc. However, that doesn't ruin the game. Not one bit. Those things are barely even noticable when most of the time, your movements and psychic powers are smooth as butter on ice. Not to mention the level designs, which accurately depict the though process of each character's brain (did I mention that the levels are just people's minds? No? Sorry about that.). And lemme tell ya, some of these levels can get interesting. These are some of the most unique levels in all of gaming. It makes you think: "Aww! Why didn't I think of that!?" Overall, the gameplay is good, but nothing revolutionary. It's fluent enough to get the story and aesthetics through, while still remaining fun.ＣＯＮＣＬＵＳＩＯＮ     Buy the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of this game. Just go.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2015
												Without a fraction of a doubt my all-time favourite game. A masterpiece of writing, this game is gut-bustingly funny. There are so many little things about this game to love and each time I play I discover something I've never seen before. The gameplay is a little loose but otherwise controls fantastically once you learn to trust the game and its design. My only issue was semi-frequent crashes, but these only occured during screen transitions and more often than not the game autosaved my progress before crashing and at worst I lost only a minute of gameplay with most of that walking. It is a small price to pay for what is in my opinion an otherwise perfect game.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2013
												The Human Mind: 600 miles of synaptic fiber, five and a half ounces of cranial fluid, 1500 grams of complex neural matter... a three-pound pile of dreams. But I'll tell you what it really is. It is the ultimate battlefield--and, the ultimate weapon. The wars of this modern age--The Psychic Age--are fought somewhere between these damp, curvaceous undulations. From this day forward, you are all psychic soldiers. Paranormal paratroopers! Mental marines who are about to ship out on the adventure of their lives! This (points to brain) is our beachhead! And this [points to head] is your landing craft. You shall engage the enemy in his own mentality--you shall chase his dreams, you shall fight his demons, you shall live his nightmares! And those of you who fight well, you will find yourselves on the path to becoming international secret agents-- in other words... Psychonauts!! The rest of you... will die!10/10 game. Would♥♥♥♥♥♥again.

												Without a fraction of a doubt my all-time favourite game. A masterpiece of writing, this game is gut-bustingly funny. The gameplay is a little loose but otherwise controls fantastically once you learn to trust the game and its design. My only issue was semi-frequent crashes, but these only occured during screen transitions and more often than not the game autosaved my progress before crashing and at worst I lost only a minute of gameplay with most of that walking. It is a small price to pay for what is in my opinion an otherwise perfect game.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
												For people who hate reviews and want a super-condensed summary: Great game, buy it.  Memorable characters, timeless art design, great story, solid platforming.  Soundtrack's great as well, it runs on pretty much anything, get hyped for Psychonauts 2.Psychonauts doesn't look impressive judging by Steam's front cover, but store pages could never be more deceiving.  Psychonauts is definitely a must-have, that much is clear.  Excellent writing and level design make for an overall memorable game with plenty of secrets and lore to find on your own.  The story is very well-done and definitely grabs you within the first hour.  Not only this, but the choice of odd, cartoonish characters make the art style rather timeless despite being an Xbox Original.Updated to be compatible with all modern platforms and with the excellent soundtrack for sale, you definitely need to get this one.  I'd talk about cons, but other than the occasional time getting lost (especially with Waterloo and the camp hubworld), I've got nothing bad to say.  Besides, let's face it, Psychonauts 2 is probably going to be excellent, so why not prepare for it?--Oh, and one last note: For a low-end PC, this game's got you covered.  I was able to play through it on a Pentium E6600 and Intel GMA... even running on something that can't handle FEAR at 12 FPS is impressive, but it was fully playable at 800x600 with this extreme example of outdated hardware.  With Intel HD, 720p with a special effect won't be in the slightest a problem, and with a low-end GPU like the GT 620, it'll run perfectly at 1080p60.  With this little discussion on the hardware required now dealt with, you have no excuse to play it.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2012
												Psychonauts was the 1st game I bought via the Steam client back in 2008 as a part of my project to fill in the missing pieces of my beloved Xbox library. Sadly this title was not optimized for PC, and features such as gamepad support were not available, rendering the game nigh unplayable. I honestly gave up on be able to play the game properly and relegated it to the bowels of my Steam inventory.Then out of nowhere last year the game received a massive developer update, adding in many of the modern Steam features we enjoy today, including gamepad support and a nice graphics update. I was very excited to finally play this game 4 years after purchase. 2005's Psychonauts even today feels like a breath of fresh air in the games industry. Its presentation and tone force you to recall what video games are inherently all about - having fun. It is really nice to have a game that does not take itself so seriously in your library, and Psychonauts is just the title to do that for you.

												It is no small task for any developer to craft a game that appeals to both the 'hardcorest' of hardcore gamers and casual players alike, but that is exactly what Double Fine has done with Psychonauts. content:
Posted: August 29, 2015
												This is probably going to just result in tons of hate mail, but I really, really did not enjoy Psychonauts. I've played and enjoyed all of Tim Schafer's previous games, but I had been putting off actually finishing this one for a while because I always got turned off by how boring the tutorial was. But I finally got around to playing it.The first thing I noticed about it is that the pacing of the story is pretty awkward. You're introduced to the camp and meet all the fellow campers (and there are a lot of them), and it seems as if you're going to be seeing them a lot, but after like the first two or three levels of the game they all vanish and don't appear again until a cutscene at the end. Considering the game's only strong point is its dialogue and humor (which it does have a fair amount of), this was a pretty big disappointment even though I didn't even like most of the campers all that much from what little time they were around. You do meet other minor characters who are unique to each mind you enter (which serve as the levels of the game), so it's not necessarily a lonely game, but the characters who are introduced after the campers' disappearance feel random and disconnected from the storyline, as if they're only there to prevent you from getting where you need to be.But the biggest thing I hated, overall, was the platforming itself. Not because it was particularly challenging, but because it was just broken. In any of the levels that were more complex than just basic "jump from one platform to the other" mechanics, I constantly ran into bugs like getting stuck grinding on the floor http://puu.sh/jSlc2/861db19a90.webm , falling to my death and losing a life because my character won't grab onto a rope http://puu.sh/jStw8/5a2a28edf1.webm , failing to climb a ladder http://puu.sh/jT1jy/bfb3130301.webm , the same for a pole http://puu.sh/jT74E/0ebc28c8d8.webm (I later realized that it doesn't happen as often if you jump from far away from the pole, but aside from that not making much sense the bug still happens fairly often like in the rope video), and many more things that I was unable to get a recording of like falling through tightropes and other inconveniences. The camera is a nightmare to control because even at max sensitivity the mouse movement is way too slow, generally leaving you at the mercy of the autocamera which can be pretty awful at times. When the game isn't breaking itself the platforming is pretty simple and easy outside of the meat circus, and there's not much to do aside from collect the tons of collectibles that every 3D platformer seems obligated to clutter its levels with, like suitcases that just cry and cry and eventually push you to shove tags into their stupid mouths just to get them to shut the ♥♥♥♥ up for five seconds while you're trying to climb up a damn ladder that your stupid character won't climb up because he's a dumb idiot.But that's not to say that the game is completely irredeemable. There are levels that only feature light platforming and take on more of a puzzle feeling, like the milk man level (which was my favorite) and a level where you have to conduct a play to find a way to reach the top of the stage, and in those levels the game is a lot of fun. And while the infamous meat circus is a nightmare featuring a timed escort mission where the escortee constantly jumps several platforms above you and starts getting attacked, it's at least the only level where I never encountered any glitches, and it provided a pretty decent challenge. The game's writing is also consistently good, and even the bad platforming levels are still very creatively designed, making me wish that they had just made it an adventure game instead of a platformer. But in the words of the wisest man I know, Mr. Krabs, "No one goes to a restaurant for atmosphere. They go for food!", and Psychonauts is no exception. It's a great game to watch and listen to, but it just isn't all that fun to play.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2013
THIS GAME SCORES [0 1 | 2 *3*] = ~88% (75%-100%)A solid double-thumbs-up. It's not a flawless ride from start to finish, but any hick-ups are easily forgotten because of the solid fun gameplay, adorable voice acting, and outstanding versatile art style. The graphics are of course somewhat dated now (2016): The game was originally released in 2006, then refurbished in 2011 (but no idea if any textures etc. were changed).The game takes place in a (small) open world (Really, where's the exact difference to a hub?) that's split into several areas. It allows access to various short and long missions which each have their unique design and often even their own gameplay elements. I would like to list a few, because they really deserve celebration, but I don't want to spoil anything.You might need some walkthrough-help from time to time, because some things that will later seem oh so clear might be too obscure at first, but the resources available on the Web are plentiful.Your time in the open hub :P is spent exploring, treasure-hunting, listening to what some characters have to say, and solving puzzles tied to your hunt for more upgrades, often involving tricky jumping/climbing. There's also a shop where you can buy stuff.I never finished the damn game because its last mission, "Meat Circus", is just too damn hard even after they supposedly softened it a few years ago, but the satisfaction up to that point is almost untainted. Really, you should wait until the game is not discounted and give them the €10 asking-price.

number of helpful: 7 of 18 people (39%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 6
												Ugh. Let us be clear here; I want it noted on the record that I desperately tried to like Psychonauts. I’d seen the praise critics and gamers heap upon it, seen the funding campaign for the sequel that many passionately gave their money to, and came back again and again to the game trying to pick apart what makes it entertaining. Despite all this, however, I only ever came to the singular conclusion which may cause people to label me as mad as the characters in the game itself; it’s just really not very fun. What makes this an especially bitter pill to swallow is the fact that, hidden deep down underneath its faults, there is the heart of something truly excellent slowly beating away, desperately trying to break free. For one, the Psychonauts universe is excellently realised; one where a great deal of love and effort has been put into it. Even with all the oddball ideas on show here, each of them is nicely fleshed out, everything linking in nicely with everything else with a remarkable consistency. Not only does this create a believable world, but this also allows the story to shine though; an oddball tale of a summer camp for children to be bred into psychic warriors under attack by mysterious forces. It's oddly compelling and excellently done, but the game's real strength comes with the sense of humour that is so excellently fed into both the story and the world beyond. Both carefully crafted jokes and throwaway one-liners by passing characters honestly made me laugh on multiple occasions, and even the most stoic of people will struggle to not crack a smile at what’s on offer here.  It’s lucky these laughs are present, however; because it’s with them that I found any sense of joy I had with the game ended - there’s just too much here that isn’t that fun for the positive side of things to truly shine through. A lot of this boils down to the gameplay that’s on offer. Whatever it is you’re doing, being it platforming or something else entirely, there always seems to be a part of it that's incredibly irritating or disappointing... Some sections outstay their welcome for far longer they were actually interesting, others are confusing or fiddly to complete, and then there’s some frustrating occasions where you're thrown into situations where the idea is amazing - yet fall flat on their face when put into practice To take an example of this last point in action -– one level sees you the size of Godzilla, tasked with stomping around a city and smashing everything in your path. Yet the actual smashing isn’t that satisfying, and your progress throughout is slow and cumbersome. Oh, and do you need to climb a building for something? Have fun crawling up at a snail’s pace, only for a single enemy shot to send you crashing down to earth the second you reach the top. There’s many a moment like that, and each is as disheartening as the last. Additionally, and somewhat ironically for a game that’s based around the mind, it feels like the gameplay of Psychonauts is incredibly schizophrenic. It’s trying out as many ideas as it can possibly cram in, but -as with the case above - many of them really don’t feel that well implemented. For instance, there's a level where you're suddenly thrown in a weird race section with absolutely no prior warning; where if you make a single mistake you’re likely to get trapped behind an obstacle and have to start the whole thing all over again. Another level takes the form of a puzzle, tasking you with collecting the right items in order to proceed; which starts off well enough and has some of the funniest moments I found. But even that soon descends into endless wandering and confusion, as you’re provided with no hints, and the solution to getting some of the items or simply making progress feels unnecessarily convoluted. And so on it goes, Psychonauts trying to be a jack of all trades, but not coming even remotely close to being a master of any of them. Another thing that doesn’t help the situation are the visuals themselves. Not with the graphics, because even I’m not stupid enough to start critiquing how good they are in a game that’s ten years old, but just in the way that everything’s just so bland looking. So many of the areas you’ll explore are a turgid mess of browns and blacks – or, if you’re lucky, some other combination of uninspiring colours. It’s something that starts in the very first level, a dreary and dull looking warzone where it’s often difficult to tell where the heck you’re meant to be going, and then just continues on from there. To add insult to injury, and at the risk of sounding incredibly contrarian, the single colourful level I played actually ended up being too much of an assault on the senses, again leading to a situation where it was hard to know where to do. It’s a shame really, because even with the possibility to create worlds limited only by the imagination, we’re left with something that’s remarkably dull and uninspired. Throw in a few other small issues, like struggling with the controls and a few tiny porting issues, and Psychonauts became to me what I can only describe as an exercise in frustration - one where I’m honestly struggling to see how it’s loved and admired by so many. Play it yourself and you may find something that I’m missing, but in my personal opinion, the whole thing is just enough to drive you crazy.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2016
												I'll start with what I dislike about this game. In my opinion, the art style is quite ugly, with all these strangely looking children and other things, emotional baggage animations, similar for acting. Parts of the theme are quite annoying (I suppose that you need to start training your psychic abilities early, that's why we have 10yo children in this game, but why do they receive so much military training, and their primary interest seems to be making out? aren't they too young for that?). The game is mostly a 3D platformer, and the 3D brings more harm than good IMHO -- in many parts of the game I was battling with the camera to show me what I want to see, and not to disrupt my controls; overall, the platforming elements were not very fun. There are lots of collectibles in the game (emotional baggage, figments of imagination, psi cards, etc.) but getting them felt more like a way to make the player spend more time on the game, rather than genuine fun -- I still did collect them, mostly because this increased my power in interesting ways, which was fun, but I think that the game would be better without all this collecting.Having said that, after learning to live with the annoying parts of the game, there were several mental worlds which were really nice -- like the one where you become a giant monster demolishing a city, one where you become a pawn in the mental board game, or one with the bull raging in the street. Still, I think these nice parts are not enough to recommend the game.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2016
												A mediocre platformer at best for me. I hated the constant interruptions of gameplay with the cutscenes every few minutes with a character explaining what you have to do next it just ruined the pacing and the flow of the game especially in this genre. If I cared for the story and characters more I wouldn’t have minded but I just didn’t for some reason, the story didn’t click for me. It’s all well voice acted and well written with some funny and clever dialogue but I struggled to keep myself engaged. The game has aged very well the art style and visual design holds up well and looks very nice at times on high resolutions and the animations feel very natural. I didn’t think a lot of the levels themselves were particularly fun or interesting. It’s a game that felt like a chore to complete, it felt like homework, It’s one of the rare games that I couldn’t bring myself to finish. Everyone talks about how underrated it is and how good it is but I didn’t feel it at all. I just didn’t have any fun with it. 4/10 (Mediocre)

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												I can understand how people enjoy this game, it's humour is pretty funny and the story (well, from what I managed to play) is really unique and interesting. However, this game is just frustrating to control and a nightmare to play. I feel like Tim may have skimped on the testing because the controls are broken and the gameplay elements just make no sense. For example, in the ♥♥♥♥♥ing Milkman level, you have to get a code by entering a random code, getting an NPC to reset the code, then reading their mind whilst they type in the new code. Don't forget, this doesn't always work. The fact it took me an hour just to complete that level says something, and at that point, I just gave up. The tightropes and grind sections take precise movement, and the game feels like it's trying to do too much at the same time. 4 psychic abilities, PSI Blast, Shield, Levitation and Invisibility would've suited, but you're shovelled with hard-to-control, awkward abilities (Telekinetic, Clairvoyence, Pyrotechnics) which the game tries to push you to use at certain points.I only went up to the asylum level and gave up because of how frustrating the game was. I appreciate a game that doesn't hold your hand, but there's a difference between that and leaving you dangling to your death on a cliff edge. I definitely hope the sequel fixes these issues.

number of helpful: 22 of 62 people (35%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												Psychonauts is definitely a charming game, with surprisingly solid writing, good sound design, and an art style that actually still looks pretty good nearly ten years after release.It's a shame, then, that the actual GAME part of the game isn't very good at all. The biggest problem with Psychonauts lies in its level design. Levels are often very confusing with no clear indication how to progress. In most collectathon platformers, that wouldn't be a major problem-- however, with few exceptions, levels in Psychonauts are rather linear, with the collectible goodies strown about the maps for you to find as you go, instead of being more open-ended and demanding exploration in order to move on. Think more Mario 3D Land and less Super Mario 64, if that helps. Puzzles often lack a clear, reasonable answer-- there were a few that I felt like I passed through sheer dumb luck-- and definitely feel like they run on point-and-click adventure logic than actual sensical game design. Speaking of game design, Psychonauts has some very questionable design decisions for a platformer. There's a few sections in the game that require copious amounts of grinding the game's currency, "arrowheads", in order to proceed. There's a few large caches of arrowheads that you can find via a boring, button-mashing game of Hot and Cold with a glorified metal detector, but there's simply not enough of these, and beyond that you'll have to repeatedly fight enemies and break destructible parts of the environment in order to scrape together enough money to buy the items that you need. Combat is stiff, bland, and tedious, ultimately amounting to little more than mashing the attack button. This, in turn, makes most of the game's boss encounters feel very lifeless.It's also fairly buggy, too. One level completely lacked voice acting on my system, as did a few other cutscenes, one cutscene repeatedly crashed my game until I completely reinstalled the game, another repeated crash also forced a reinstall, and in two different occasions I had to restart the game back to the menu because of getting stuck on pieces of the environment. There are other little nitpicks too-- the controls can be woefully unresponsive at times, at least using the keyboard and mouse, and occasionally the games physics feel a bit wonky.Finally, and admittedly this might seem a bit minor, trying to collect all of the "figments" in the game is a total nightmare. Their locations often defy rhyme or reason, many of them move, but most irritatingly, on the more colourful levels they often blend into the environment due to the fact that they are translucent. Completionists had best prepare for tedious backtracking through levels desperately double-checking that they didn't miss one in the walls. Also, the final type of collectible feels very token and throwaway as they are strown about quite liberally in the last three sections of the hub-area with very little effort. A nitpick, but still rather jarring.It's a darn shame, really. I can at least TELL why Psychonauts is something of a cult classic-- very few games have the personality that it does. But personality only goes so far when the actual gameplay holds it down, and in Psychonauts' case the gameplay is an anchor around its neck, dragging it kicking and screaming into the murky depths of mediocrity.

number of helpful: 45 of 114 people (39%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												I wouldn't recommend the game. It depends on what you are looking for.I was looking for a good platformer so I was disappointed when I saw that the platforming of the game is very basic and it's not very well executed. The psychic powers that you get make a good amount of jumps way too easy, you just don't have to follow the rules of a platformer.If you are looking for other things, this may be your game. It has comedy everywhere and the art is just amazing. The "worlds" that you visit are very interesting. It's clear than whoever thought about how to show the different minds gave a lot of thought to it.Unfortunately that doesn't make the game fun to play. Most of the time is just too "plain" and easy and when it gets difficult it is not because the platforming or enemies are difficult but because you can't tell the background from a place to jump into/grab to.A good point about it is that it adds more and more powers and different gameplay along the game, so it isn't always the same and you get to do some interesting things to solve puzzles.While I was playing the game I found myself thinking "When will it end?" and that's clearly not a good sign. I will finish it (I am at the end now) because I can't accept not finishing a game I started if it's not completely horrible and this one has good moments.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
												For the most part, it's a very well designed and playable game, featuring well-realized platforming and combat mechanics and an engaging and amusing story populated with likable characters.It's in the Windows implementation that the game falters, and falters badly.  Crashes to the desktop on loading a level are VERY common, although the autosave feature mitigates the effect of these.Far more severe, however, are the instances when the game simply stops responding altogether while attempting to load a level.  It becomes stuck in full-screen mode and won't respond---even to Alt-TAB or Ctrl-Alt-Delete!  Under these circumstances, all progress since the last save will be lost.In all the decades that I've been using Windows, I've encountered only a handful of programs that "hang" so badly that it's literally necessary to power down the PC or disconnect it from the power supply in order to recover.  Unfortunately this is one of them.

number of helpful: 6 of 27 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
												I have fond memories of Banjo-Kazooie. Having heard high praise of Psychonauts and hearing it was in a similar tone and style, it seemed like a perfect fit.But I was never drawn in by it's whimsy like a was the old N64 platformers. That's pretty big shame because that seems to be a big draw to this game. Some mechanics seem illconceived, regardless of it's age. Some levels are fine, but other are frustrating in ways that are unnecessary. These tend to be levels that rely heavily on precise platforming in ways that 3D platforming is not meant for.What capped off my experience with Psychonauts was the Meat Circus level: three 3D platforming sections divided by escort missions. None of this is checkpointed, so failing any section will start you back at the beginning.My frustration Psychonauts makes me wonder if a modern 3D platformer can be successful.

number of helpful: 2 of 19 people (11%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
												All across the Internet, gamers and critics have agreed on very few things. However, in the last decade, there has been one universal statement: “You should play Psychonauts.” In fact, more people have probably said that aloud than actually seen the whole thing through. At the time, the game was the first step of a beloved creator and his independent band of misfits known as Double Fine. It is still brought up today for its creativity, its originality, and its unique premise. However, without the rose tinted glasses, in the age of 1,000 indies, does the game hold up? Is Psychonauts truly the timeless classic it seemed destined to be? After playing the game for the first time in 2015, I think I’ve come to an answer.Want to know more? My full review is available over at TechRaptor.com! http://techraptor.net/content/psychonauts-retro-review-pain-membrane

number of helpful: 52 of 134 people (39%) found this review helpful7 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												Yeah yeah... I don't recommend your most favorite game of all time...This was my first time playing Psychonauts, no nostalgia filter. Some of the praise holds true. Levels are extremely creative, changing the game up slightly with each set-piece. Many characters are hilarious and unique as well, even if 60% of them have ear-bleedingly annoying voice actors.But dear god, cutscenes, boss fights (the classic "dodge his attacks three times and then use your new ability on him" boss fights), cutscenes (yes, I know I wrote it twice), and janky PC combat controls. Platforming is awkward, especially with the wonky self-controlling camera. Some puzzles were clever but had downright esoteric solutions.If you're looking for a classic combat platforming game, go Sly Cooper, go Jak and Daxter, go Ratchet and Clank. This game was a grind of boredom, frustration, and brief moments of funny banter.You may now downrate my review.

number of helpful: 11 of 42 people (26%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7, 2014
												I would love to rave about Psychonauts, about the art style, characters, dialogue, humour and level design. I would love to, but I can't.I can't because of the god-awful controls. Though, to be honest, describing them as god-awful is being kind. Playing with a mouse and keyboard is borderline impossible and whilst playing with a controller did improve things, it still wasn't great. Playing Psychonauts is like being sat at the cinema with a hyperactive toddler poking you in the eye every minute or so. No matter how good the film is, you can't enjoy it due to being constantly poked in the eye. Which is a genuine shame as Psychonauts is a great game, it's funny and weird and well-designed in terms of level design, character design and story. But just as you're in the middle of enjoying the funny, well designed and artistic weirdness, along comes the poke in the eye that is the controls to overshadow the whole thing. There is simply no escaping the poke in the eye.So, as much as I'd love to shout from the rooftops and tell the world to buy and play the game, as much as I'd like to call it a must-play and a classic, I simply can't recommend it, I can't recommend that people endure being poked in the eye.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												Let me preface this review by saying that this game is amazing.  The story is great, the dialogue is funny and captivating and the character development is 10/10.  Let me follow by saying that you should not play it.  So basically, it is a great game with one fatal flaw that eventually made me quit.  I played for 10 hours or so and loved the story, but then I quit right at the end out of frustration.  The controls suck.  I would fail simple tasks because of the way they ported the controls.  You know how with some games it's obvious that they just straight ported from a console without much thought to controls? Well, this is one of those games.  I really wish I could have finished it, but I ended up having to watch the ending on youtube.  Either connect your controller to the PC, or dont play it.  It's really a shame, too, because this game is so great.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												This will probably take a lot of heat, but I was never much of a fan of Psyconauts.I found the original to have terrible Camera Controls, which, for a 3d platformer is usually a death sentence, however; continuing on. While the humour is generally good, it really grown anymore loveable over the years. Diologue feels stilted and the Graphics, while excellent for their time, have not aged well. Horrendous screen tearing and a some of the worst pop in I have seen from a game since San Andreas (which had an excuse btw) occurs.While the game never outstays it's welcome, backtracking becomes a nessesity. If you have the game and wanted to revisit it on PC, dont bother. The game really starts to show its age with resolutions. And if you wanted to pick it up because it's a classic, buy it boxed. Or better yet, rent it. While I cant recommend you buying it, Psychonauts is a humourous romp through an interesting land. If you buy it in the humble bundle, I say give this a whirl. You may like it more than me.

number of helpful: 6 of 35 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												Psychonauts is a game I very much wanted to like but a mix of poor stability, not really it's fault, and a lack of immersion or engagement prevented me from actually finishing it. I know this will upset fans of the game but it just stopped being fun for me.This is a pretty old game but, in the ways we normally define the term, it has aged well, the writing is still funny and while the cartoonish graphics style is obviously older it doesn't suffer from the same issues older "realistically" styled games do. The issue I had with it's age was stability. Instances of saves not saving, stuttering, and mid session crashes (with a particularly aggravating habit of crashing right after a boss encounter before you can save) make the game start to feel like a grind pretty quickly. With a game I really like and enjoy this would either be viewed as a mild inconvenience or I would have the motivation to find a solution but with Psychonauts that motivation just wasn't there.I will say that the writing is quite good for a "kids" game. Think Pixar and the way they take a medium, animation, typically seen as "for kids" and make it accessible and enjoyable for adults. From what I played the characters are children but they do not behave in the typical way video game children do, whiny and annoying and/or totally helpless.The platforming is average at best and, while better than first-person platforming, it shows that platforming is at it's best in 2 or 2.5 dimensions. The controls were not what you would describe as tight which does not help the platforming. Even with my mouse turned all the way up the camera still felt too slow. It's possible using a gamepad would alleviate some of this.In the end I wish there was a way to play this game and experience the story with about 50% of the guff in the middle removed. The full price is not too steep but I would probably recommend waiting for a sale or bundle to pick it up due to bugs possibly preventing you from fully experiencing the game. As your experience with this game may be completely different than mine or anyone else's (hence the term cult classic) it's still probably worth a look at the right price.

Generally you would think that someone who created Monkey Island, Stacking, and Costume Quest would be someone I would love.  Yet I have to admit that in general I find Tim Schaefer and his work lacking.   Lets take Psychonauts, the Art style is something I simply cant enjoy at any point.  I spend a few minutes and I have to turn it off its so horrble looking.  The gameplay was boring and felt way to hipster for me.  Which is always what I feel Tim shoots for in his work, way too much wacky concepts thrown into a world with questionable play style.    I give Psychonauts a 30/100 Bad

number of helpful: 4 of 33 people (12%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2013
												This is a game that's fun to watch but not to play. To get the most from it, buy it as a gift for your roommate and watch them play it, or play it as a party game and hand the controller to someone you don't like... but if you're considering this as a solo experience, you're better off just watching clips of the funniest bits on youtube. You'll get all the humor and none of the frustration.Don't believe the good reviews. Yes, the characters, voice acting, plot, humor, etc. are every bit as good as you've heard, and some of the levels are wildly creative.Here's what the reviews didn't mention:- The camera moves all the time without you asking it to, and keeping it pointed at the thing you want to look at requires continuously moving the mouse.- The last level, Meat Circus, is the worst level ever designed in any video game. Check the steam achievements -- most players uninstall the game at that point rather than suffer through it.- Many of the levels (the ones you don't see in all the review videos) are just uninspired platforming sections filled with mario-style collection quests.- 3rd-person platforming is really frustrating when the camera keeps moving.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 18, 2012
												One of the best, most creative games ever. Hilarious and entertaining to watch, and also a lotta fun to play. Psychonauts deserved to do so much better in the market. The amount of love the creators poured into this shows in every detail. (Remember to use the Mind's Eye power on absolutely everything in the game to see dozens of characters' interpretations of the main player). Having each level be the inside of someone's mind is a brilliant concept and it works beautifully. Seriously, buy this game so they can make more like it. It's currently $5 on the steam summer sale, but you're still basically stealing a great work of art at the regular $10 too. Tim Schafer has earned your money. Also, I highly recommend using a controller from the console you probably own, it's so much better than m+kb for this one.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 24, 2013
												This game is a gem from the PS2 era. Simple, charming, funny, imaginative. It's a 3rd person action game in which you must save everybody and specifically their brains. The story progresses linearly, but the player is free to roam and replay the levels.  The game is not very difficult and can be played by young children as well as older people with a silly sense of humor. This is why you should play it: -Throughout the game you unlock new psychic powers (the ability to set things on fire, invisiblity, telekinesis etc. ) -Parts of the game takes place inside the minds of the characters. That makes for crazy, diverse and colourful game environments. -there are little anecdotes to discover from and about the other characters. I found them highly amusing.-There are plenty of collectibles to find (if you're into that. I certainly am) -It has jokes! fun! Hilarious characters and bacon!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												this game is available via every means possible, i am seriously surprised it isn't on ios and android, or the ouya for that matter. it has stood the test of time, and has been commended profusely by pretty much everyone has played it. so is it worth all that praise? does it actually hold up today?yeah.. pretty much. the graphics are stylish, cartoony and fun. the gameplay is stays consistently fun and interesting through the entirety of the game. just when things start to stagnate, and you start to get bored with the current challenge, it throws a curve ball to keep things rolling.i think the main reason to play this game to the end is the story and characters, i mean, i wouldn't have if the game itself wasn't fun, but i was really darn enthralled by all the wacky and sympathetic characters. i don't think there is a single archetypal character in this game, which alone makes it worth playing. I really love the attitude that everyone treats Raz with, it is always cautionary, but with a level of respect.anyways, if you've somehow not gotten around to trying this game, i really recommend you give it a shot.one last note, do not get discouraged by the collectables, they stay relevant through the whole game, but they are really not that important, so don't let them taint your impression of the game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												This has quickly become my favorite game. It has creativity, humor, excellent writing, many characters each with their own dynamic personality, and best of all a story that delves deep into the deep crevasses of the human psyche while keeping a cartoony tone. It also forms a good juxtaposition of incredible humor, and dark themes. However, the gameplay can get a little frustrating at times, there were a couple platforming segments that took many tries for me to finish. Also the game isn't incredibly well optimised, there where a couple parts where my frame rate chugged a bit (and my PC is pretty high end). But all that can be overlooked if you don't just concentrate on the gameplay and delve into the artfully crafted experience. Well worth it and if you are looking for an incredibly creative narrative experience then I highly suggest Psychonauts.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												This is a platformer that thrives on exploration. Abundant collectables encourage you to investigate every nook and cranny with the promise of promotion and a new array of powers which then allow you to search more thoroughly. While exploring an area, you inadvertently explore the people associated with it and that's where this game really shines, everything has personality. Whether it's the interactions between the campers or the various apparitions that populate the residents' minds, everything has its own motivation and purpose, everything is engaging. This is what makes exploring so enjoyable: it's always rewarding. It seems fitting then, in a game that revels in open exploration, that things sort of fall apart when the game goes on rails (often literally). The ending sequence ties up the plot perfectly and it shouldn't have ended any other way, but the game, while still enjoyable, ceases to be fun. The platforming stops being forgiving in order to ramp up the difficultly and make the conclusion satisfying, but its forgiving nature is what stopped all of its flaws from peeking through. Poor camera angles, controls that don't always function correctly, and sloppy physics which were perfectly ignorable come to a head during the final sequence. I enjoyed the game as a whole, but I was happy to be done with it by the end. It still a good game, maybe even an amazing one, but desperately in need of some more polish.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 28, 2014
												This is the game that earned Double Fine their reputation. It's quite possible that this game is the only reason Double Fine has had the funding to create things like a game about matryoshka dolls, a half-finished point-and-click Kickstarter game, an RPG/RTS about living inside a Motorhead/Iron Maiden album cover, and tons of other interesting stuff. And that reputation isn't undeserved.Psychonauts is one of the most original, most enjoyable, and certainly most memorable games of the last decade. The game is a labor of love from Double Fine, and it shows: every corner of the world absolutely oozes style and attention to detail. You'll attend a summer camp for the psychically gifted and meet agents of a global psychic agency that's fallen into decline. You'll jump into the brain of a lungfish and discover that it is legion. You'll fight the parts of your brain that stamp out erroneous thoughts, and deal with the rampaging emotions of a once-famous bullfighter. You'll strike up a teenage romance and rescue brains in jars so your friends can stop watching TV.Play this game. It's a piece of history and it's thoroughly enjoyable to boot.

												Quite nice but it is obviously made by someone who hasn't made a jump and run/platformer before. Right at the end (I think) is an escort mission. Yeah, you can imagine how that goes (I wanted to switch sides and kill the person I had to escort and stopped playing/trying to complete that mission for now).Other than that it is really fun.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												Practically perfect in every way. Play as a 10 year old kid who ran away from the circus to train at a psychic summer camp for gifted children. And all of those kids are wonderful, hilarious, and endlessly stupid, and so are the staff. Spend lliterally all your time using all your new psychic abilities on every single character in the game, because the devs thought of everything and every character reacts differently to being set on fire, levitated, or having you invading their mind. The game also features some of the most stunning, insane and mindblowing level design, which makes it even easier to just fluff around, discovering every secret and item. But the game isn't all just fun and mind games, despite being delightful and witty, there is a dark undercurrent that runs throughout. This adds a depth and emotional balance that is refreshing and very rare for any videogame. You'll be happily bouncing around a vibrant level, when out of nowhere you'll stumble on somthing absolutely chilling and haunting, because when you are snooping around in other people's heads, you'll run across things that they want to stay hidden. All of this culminates in the final boss level, which I can only describe as some sort of hell dimension. It is completely punishing, you will suffer in ways you never thought possible. You will throw things and scream, and give up multiple times, but you will keep coming back, because you can't let this stupid level beat you damnit. 10/10 best game I have ever played. So good I bought it for steam after already owning it on xbox. It's THAT good.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 13, 2014
												If you like fun and do not totally despise platformers, get it. (Then again, this game is more than a normal platformer.)The game is beautiful, creative and filled with humor. Most of the screen shots do not do it justice. It can be a bit goofy, but there is some charm in that. Basically, it's the good kind of goofy.This game is full of colorful characters and everything is spoken. No text scenes, every word has a voice.  Double Fine put a lot of thought in this game, just about every person or enemy reacts differently to the same thing. Scan Lili, she sees you as a prince, scan the right Ford and you'll be a pile of leaves.My game has gotten glitchy near the end, but all I need to do to fix it is exit out of the game and start it again. Sometimes the fix lasts longer than others.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												This is the game that started my lifelong love for Double Fine. Psychonauts is the greatest platformer of all time. In a seemingly cartoony world, you’re presented with deep metaphorical characters and environments alongside some of the most fun and fluid gameplay to date.Gameplay - The combat and collection items is similar to most popular platformers. The stages are all vastly different from one another and are mostly explored through NPC's minds via the camp grounds, meaning each mind is completely different from the last.Music - The music meshes well with everything.Graphics - It’s been years since its release and I would love to see an HD update for the game, but they still hold up well. Each world gives us off a different vibe, but they remain vibrant and aesthetically pleasing. For those completely new to Double Fine, expect a Tim Burton-esque feel. Overall Score: 9.5/10

content:
Posted: December 30, 2011
												There are only a few games that could ever be considered perfect, this is one of them.  First off, the aesthetic of this game is just amazing, not only does it fit perfectly with everything that goes on in it, but  the story and gameplay would have suffered without this look. The story itself is sheer greatness, going from something trivial to something monumental seamlessly. The gameplay is something you will never find again, and is just damn fun. When you get the abilities it never feels like you go through a tutorial for them, but just playing the game. At one point I actually wondered why this was taking so long to finish, and that's a good thing. EVERY character is fully fleshed out with different personalities that are all explored. Why the game takes place in the short amount of time it does, why you are the chosen one, have great acrobatic skill, why you can't swim, how some of the abilities are portrayed, even the lives, health and ammo systems just seem natural. BUY IT!

Posted: July 3, 2011
												Psychonauts is a cult game: it didn't make a lot of money, people only discovered it years after it was realeased, it's different from everything that came before and influenced a lot that came afterwards. Brainchild of Tim Schafer (the guy that made Monkey Island, Grim Fandango, Brütal Legend, etc), Psychonauts has a great storyline, some of the most creative level design I've ever seen, and it's fun (and funny) as hell.My only bone to pick w/ it, is it's frustratingly hard last level - but I suppose it's alright feeling psychotic playing Psychonauts. Buy it and then write an e-mail to Schaffer asking for a sequel.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 12, 2014
												This game is awesome. ......Good, you're still here. Psychonauts is a platforming adventure game by Double Fine, and I'll keep the list of reasons for it being awesome short and to the point:* Using psychic abilities to delve into people's minds allows for a unique method of story telling - you can learn a surprising amount about a character just from their mind's architecture, as well as hidden memories in slideshow format.* The humour is done extremely well, and gels seamlessly with the cartoonish graphics. * The finale is epic, and I don't care how many players complain about it being difficult. Speaking of which...* You get an in-game help system, so nobody is allowed to complain that a level was too obtuse because all you had to do  was use said system.* Much like Deus Ex, every game mechanic is explained in-story, providing some great immersion,And now, regrettably, a list of the game's flaws:* You can only use three psychic powers at a time - likely a concession to gamepads and consoles. This annoyingly means that you have to customise a 'loadout' for at least every boss fight, regardless of how useful a fourth would have be. Want to shield against a boss' attacks while bouncing around and using invisibility to avoid them too? Tough, because there are always one or two powers that are mandatory to beat a boss.* The kinetic power has a weird control, as you use the same keys to throw stuff around that you do to move around - this is also likely for gamepads and controllers.* One of the main antagonists has no boss fight whatsoever, and is dispatched easily in a cutscene with barely any development or even screentime.* The smart camera works fine for the most part, but one area of the final level is very annoying and manual control of it was necessary to pass.* The new powers gained through Psi-Ranks tend to unbalance one particular level's bossfights, or rather wrestling matches. Agility and rolling out of the way isn't really a thing when you have an all-powerful shield that stops all damage for a length of time.* However, this should in no way stop you from buying Psychonauts, as it is, as I've said, and awesome game.
